After a brief Cook County court hearing Tuesday on the case, attorney Adam Sheppard, who represents ex-professor Wyndham Lathem, 44, said he looked forward to attacking the credibility of Andrew Warren at a trial that he estimated could be months away.\xe2\x80\x9cSeems like another co-defendant who\xe2\x80\x99s guilty, who\xe2\x80\x99s shifting blame,\xe2\x80\x9d Sheppard said at the Leighton Criminal Court Building. \xe2\x80\x9cSo we don\xe2\x80\x99t support (Warren\xe2\x80\x99s) credibility. We take great issue with it."In a plea deal Monday, Warren, 58, admitted to the fatal stabbing of Lathem\xe2\x80\x99s boyfriend, 26-year-old Trenton Cornell-Duranleau, and agreed to cooperate in return for prosecutors recommending a 45-year prison sentence.Prosecutors have said that Warren, from England, and Lathem, then an associate professor of microbiology at Northwestern, plotted the sex-fantasy killing online for months. Cornell-Duranleau was stabbed some 70 times in Lathem\xe2\x80\x99s posh high-rise apartment in Chicago\xe2\x80\x99s Near North neighborhood in July 2017.Warren signed an agreement Monday that laid out the terms of the deal in writing \xe2\x80\x94 a somewhat rare event in Cook County criminal court. But Judge Charles Burns ordered the plea deal sealed, saying he wanted to confer first with Lathem\xe2\x80\x99s attorneys at their previously scheduled court date Tuesday.On Tuesday, Burns met twice with prosecutors and Lathem\xe2\x80\x99s attorneys privately in his chambers for about a combined half an hour. When he emerged, the judge said Warren\xe2\x80\x99s plea deal could be made public as soon as Wednesday after one paragraph had been removed. Burns said he was unsure if information in that paragraph had previously been made public.Speaking to reporters later, Sheppard said the paragraph contained information that would be \xe2\x80\x9cvery prejudicial\xe2\x80\x9d to Lathem\xe2\x80\x99s right to a fair jury if it were releasedCiting similar concerns, Burns has issued a \xe2\x80\x9cgag order\xe2\x80\x9d on attorneys and ordered key court filings sealed from public view.mcrepeau@chicagotribune.com

An injured bear has been spotted roaming through Palm Coast neighborhoods over the past two weeks and animal activists are asking residents to stop reporting the sightings to law enforcement as a way to protect the bear's life.The Flagler Humane Society posted an update Saturday on its Facebook page regarding an adult black bear that's been seen limping through the F and C sections of Palm Coast and near Old Kings Road. The post indicates the bear has suffered a leg injury that should heal on its own over time and Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission officials are aware of the bear's presence.The social media post urges residents to use safety precautions and refrain from reporting the bear sightings to keep conservation commission officers from feeling compelled to trap or euthanize the animal.[READ MORE: Traveling Florida black bear spotted in Palm Coast]\"The bear is not being a nuisance, which is why they have allowed him to continue traveling versus relocating,\" the post states. \"Due to the calls of people saying they are in fear, it will put the bear's life at risk for euthanasia if the Wildlife Commission and the sheriff's department continue to receive so many calls of fears for citizens' safety.\"But Wildlife Commission spokesman Chad Weber said the state agency would never tell people not to call and report bear activity if they feel unsafe, indicating it takes more than a heavy concentration of phone calls to trigger department officials to take deadly action on wildlife. The bear would first have to exhibit aggressive behavior, threatening people, property or livestock.\"The only reason we would euthanize a bear is if they broke into somebody's home, somebody's vehicle, or if it attacked a person,\" Weber said Monday. \"Normally we try to trap them and relocate them if at all possible.\"By Tuesday, the Facebook update had garnered more than 800 likes and shares. Amy Carotenuto, executive director of the Flagler Humane Society, admitted the wording of the online post may have been a bit off, but the goal is to keep people from panicking if they spot the bear.\"We wanted people to realize that just because he's big, it doesn't mean he's going to chase after you and try to eat you,\" Carotenuto said Tuesday. \"We tear apart forests, we build houses and developments on top of wetlands. We're encroaching on their territory, so we're going to see wild animals the more we keep developing.\"The Flagler County Sheriff's Office has received a handful of calls concerning the bear since July 15, dispatch records show. In three of the reports, callers took note that the bear appeared to be limping on one of its hind legs. None of the reports indicated the bear was aggressive or a nuisance.Black bears are no longer included on the Wildlife Commission's list of threatened or endangered species. Nonetheless, it is still illegal for residents to harm or kill the animals without permission from the state agency, according to the state's Black Bear Conservation rule. Sheriff's Office spokeswoman Brittany Kershaw said it is always the Wildlife Commission's decision on how to handle the calls.\"Typically, we'll receive the reports since we answer the 9-1-1 and non-emergency lines,\" Kershaw said Monday. \"But we always refer those reports to FWC. And then they make the determination whether to come out or notData shows the Wildlife Commission handled 17 bear-related calls through all of 2018. So far this year, the agency has received 20 such calls, seven of which came in July, records indicate.

Minnesota Public Radio and the Star Tribune are proud to announce the 20th season of Talking Volumes.\xc2\xa0Talking Volumes is hosted by award-winning journalist Kerri Miller.\xc2\xa0This season the events take place in St.\xc2\xa0Paul at the Fitzgerald Theater and Minneapolis at The Parkway Theater.The following book descriptions are provided by the publishers.Location:\xc2\xa0The Fitzgerald Theater \xc2\xa0Get ticketsFrom the New York Times best-selling author of The Dovekeepers\xc2\xa0and The Marriage of Opposites\xc2\xa0comes Alice Hoffman's darkly magical story of in a heartbreaking time of war when men became monsters,\xc2\xa0children navigated a world without parents,\xc2\xa0and women were willing to sacrifice everything for those they loved.What does it mean to lose your mother?\xc2\xa0What makes a family?\xc2\xa0How is it possible to survive cruelty and continue to love?\xc2\xa0In a life that is as unreal as a fairy tale,\xc2\xa0Alice Hoffman's The World That We Knew\xc2\xa0takes us on a journey of loss and resistance,\xc2\xa0good and evil,\xc2\xa0the fantastical and the mortal,\xc2\xa0to a place where all roads lead past the angel of death and love is never-ending.Location:\xc2\xa0The Parkway Theater \xc2\xa0Get ticketsFrom award-winning poet Saeed Jones,\xc2\xa0How We Fight for Our Lives is a stunning coming-of-age memoir written at the crossroads of sex,\xc2\xa0race,\xc2\xa0and power.Haunted and haunting,\xc2\xa0Jones'\xc2\xa0memoir tells the story of a young,\xc2\xa0black,\xc2\xa0gay man from the South as he fights to carve out a place for himself,\xc2\xa0within his family,\xc2\xa0within his country,\xc2\xa0within his own hopes,\xc2\xa0desires,\xc2\xa0and fears.\xc2\xa0Through a series of vignettes that chart a course across the American landscape,\xc2\xa0Jones draws listeners into his boyhood and adolescence -\xc2\xa0into tumultuous relationships with his mother and grandmother,\xc2\xa0into passing flings with lovers,\xc2\xa0friends and strangers.\xc2\xa0Each piece builds into a larger examination of race and queerness,\xc2\xa0power and vulnerability,\xc2\xa0love and grief:\xc2\xa0a portrait of what we all do for\xc2\xa0one another \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0and to\xc2\xa0one another \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0as we fight to become ourselves.Blending poetry and prose,\xc2\xa0Jones has developed a style that is equal parts sensual,\xc2\xa0beautiful,\xc2\xa0and powerful \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0a voice that's by turns a river,\xc2\xa0a blues,\xc2\xa0and a nightscape set ablaze.\xc2\xa0How We Fight for Our Lives\xc2\xa0is a one-of-a-kind memoir that cements Saeed Jones as an essential writer for our time.Location:\xc2\xa0The Parkway Theater \xc2\xa0Get ticketsBest-selling author Tim O\xe2\x80\x99Brien shares wisdom from a life in letters,\xc2\xa0lessons learned in wartime,\xc2\xa0and the challenges,\xc2\xa0humor,\xc2\xa0and rewards of raising two sons.

In 2003,\xc2\xa0already an older father,\xc2\xa0National Book Award\xe2\x80\x93winning novelist Tim O\xe2\x80\x99Brien resolved to give his young sons what he wished his own father had given to him \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0a few scraps of paper signed \xe2\x80\x9cLove,\xc2\xa0Dad.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Maybe a word of advice.\xc2\xa0Maybe a sentence or two about some long-ago Christmas Eve.\xc2\xa0Maybe some scattered glimpses of their rapidly aging father,\xc2\xa0a man they might never really know.\xc2\xa0For the next fifteen years,\xc2\xa0the author talked to his sons on paper,\xc2\xa0as if they were adults,\xc2\xa0imagining what they might want to hear from a father who was no longer among the living.

The result is Dad\xe2\x80\x99s Maybe Book,\xc2\xa0a funny,\xc2\xa0tender,\xc2\xa0wise and enduring literary achievement that will squeeze the reader\xe2\x80\x99s heart with joy and recognition.Location:\xc2\xa0The Fitzgerald Theater \xc2\xa0Get ticketsIn this timely and important book,\xc2\xa0one of the most trusted and admired writers on the world of faith examines the meaning of Scripture.\xc2\xa0The sacred texts have been co-opted by fundamentalists,\xc2\xa0who insist that they must be taken literally,\xc2\xa0and by others who interpret Scripture to bolster their own prejudices.\xc2\xa0These texts are seen to prescribe ethical norms and codes of behavior that are divinely ordained:\xc2\xa0they are believed to contain eternal truths.\xc2\xa0But as Karen Armstrong shows in this chronicle of the development and significance of major religions,\xc2\xa0such a narrow,\xc2\xa0peculiar reading of Scripture is a relatively recent,\xc2\xa0modern phenomenon.\xc2\xa0For most of their history,\xc2\xa0the world's religious traditions have regarded these texts as tools that enable the individual to connect with the divine,\xc2\xa0to experience a different level of consciousness,\xc2\xa0and to help them engage with the world in more meaningful and compassionate ways.

At a time of intolerance and mutual incomprehension,\xc2\xa0The Lost Art of Scripture\xc2\xa0shines fresh light on the world's major religions to help us build bridges between faiths and rediscover a creative and spiritual engagement with holy texts.Location:\xc2\xa0The Fitzgerald Theater \xc2\xa0Get ticketsFirebrand NY Times\xc2\xa0columnist and author of the critically acclaimed memoir and Hulu TV series Shrill,\xc2\xa0Lindy West,\xc2\xa0provides a laugh-out-loud,\xc2\xa0incisive cultural critique that answers the fundamental question of this hellish political moment--how did we get here?--by dissecting the films,\xc2\xa0television series,\xc2\xa0internet phenomena,\xc2\xa0and lifestyle gurus that have taught us who we are.\xc2\xa0And,\xc2\xa0more importantly,\xc2\xa0what happens when people start saying "no."The conditions that fostered the catastrophic resentment and abetted Trump's victory did not spring up in a vacuum;\xc2\xa0they are woven into America's DNA.\xc2\xa0The Witches Are Coming will explore how we got here through a long lens of pop culture,\xc2\xa0dissecting the stories we've been telling ourselves about ourselves \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0and each other \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0for generations,\xc2\xa0the assumptions we swallow as fact and the facts we deny,\xc2\xa0and the disastrous death-grip of mediocre white men on our past century's art and media.\xc2\xa0The Witches Are Coming was named one of Esquire's most anticipated books of 2019.\xc2\xa0Location:\xc2\xa0The Fitzgerald Theater \xc2\xa0Get ticketsIn Wade in the Water,\xc2\xa0Tracy K.\xc2\xa0Smith boldly ties America's contemporary moment both to our nation's fraught founding history and to a sense of the spirit,\xc2\xa0the everlasting.\xc2\xa0These are poems of sliding scale:\xc2\xa0some capture a flicker of song or memory;\xc2\xa0some collage an array of documents and voices;\xc2\xa0and some push past the known world into the haunted,\xc2\xa0the holy.\xc2\xa0Smith's signature voice \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0inquisitive,\xc2\xa0lyrical and wry \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0turns over what it means to be a citizen,\xc2\xa0a mother,\xc2\xa0and an artist in a culture arbitrated by wealth,\xc2\xa0men,\xc2\xa0and violence.\xc2\xa0Here,\xc2\xa0private utterance becomes part of a larger choral arrangement as the collection widens to include erasures of The Declaration of Independence and the correspondence between slave owners,\xc2\xa0a found poem comprised of evidence of corporate pollution and accounts of near-death experiences,\xc2\xa0a sequence of letters written by African Americans enlisted in the Civil War,\xc2\xa0and the survivors'\xc2\xa0reports of recent immigrants and refugees.\xc2\xa0Wade in the Water\xc2\xa0is a potent and luminous book by one of America's essential poets.Kerri Miller joined Minnesota Public Radio in June 2004 as host of Minnesota Public Radio's Midmorning and Talking Volumes,\xc2\xa0the joint book club of MPR,\xc2\xa0the Star Tribune in collaboration with the Loft Literary Center.\xc2\xa0She has been a radio and television news reporter since 1981.\xc2\xa0She has won numerous awards,\xc2\xa0including the Society of Professional Journalists National Achievement Award,\xc2\xa0Minnesota Broadcasters Award,\xc2\xa0the Associated Press Award and a Gracie award from the Association of Women in Radio and TelevisionTalking Volumes,\xc2\xa0a partnership of Minnesota Public Radio\xc2\xa0and the Star Tribune,\xc2\xa0in collaboration with The Loft Literary Center,\xc2\xa0is a winner of the prestigious Gracie Allen Award.\xc2\xa0Talking Volumes was noted for its superior quality in writing,\xc2\xa0production and programming.\xc2\xa0The program spotlights books with feature articles,\xc2\xa0live broadcasts with the author,\xc2\xa0in-person readings and discussions,\xc2\xa0and more.Tickets can be purchased online at MPREvents.org\xc2\xa0starting at 10 a.m.\xc2\xa0Tuesday,\xc2\xa0July 23,\xc2\xa02019.\xc2\xa0Fitzgerald tickets can also be purchased in person at First Ave ticket outlets.\xc2\xa0The Fitzgerald has reserved seating and the Parkway is general admission.\xc2\xa0Both venues will include musicians,\xc2\xa0real-time open captioning,\xc2\xa0book sales and signings with the authors.Sept.\xc2\xa025:\xc2\xa0Music by Tiny Deaths at the Fitzgerald Theater Oct.\xc2\xa09:\xc2\xa0Music by Touissant Morrison at the Parkway TheaterOct.\xc2\xa016:\xc2\xa0Music by Molly Maher at the Parkway TheaterNov.\xc2\xa07:\xc2\xa0Music by K.Raydio at the Fitzgerald Theater Nov.\xc2\xa014:\xc2\xa0Music by Chris Koza at the Fitzgerald Theater Nov.\xc2\xa021:\xc2\xa0Music by Lady Midnight at the Fitzgerald Theater The shows will be recorded for broadcast on MPR News.\xc2\xa0Doors open at 6 p.m.\xc2\xa0and shows start at 7 p.m.\xc2\xa0Check out MPR News podcasts from the award-winning 74 Seconds to in-depth conversations on news and culture with Kerri Miller and our daily news updates.

column4: Los Angeles County, California, United States
column5:
\n

Spahn\xe2\x80\xaf Ranch housed Charles Manson and his family at the time they \xe2\x80\xafwere \xe2\x80\xafcommitting brutal murders.\xe2\x80\xafCharles Manson\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xafis infamous for leading the\xc2\xa0cult that brutally\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0killed\xc2\xa0nine\xc2\xa0people\xe2\x80\xafwithin five weeks\xe2\x80\xaf \xe2\x80\x94 one victim was actress\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0Sharon Tate, who was eight months pregnant when she was \xe2\x80\xafmurdered.\xe2\x80\xaf\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0Before the carnage began, however, the Family lived together as an almost stereotypical 1960s-era hippie commune, making their home at a ranch with a rich history in Hollywood Westerns.\xc2\xa0Spahn Ranch was a sprawling \xe2\x80\xafLos Angeles County property\xc2\xa0in the valley, at which a number of Western television shows and movies \xe2\x80\x94 including \xe2\x80\x9cBonanza,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lone Ranger,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIsis\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 were filmed. \xe2\x80\xafGeorge Spahn purchased the property in 1953, and as the Western genre waned in popularity, so would the demand to use the site.\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0Spahn\xc2\xa0was in need of\xc2\xa0a way to make money: He started to diversify by using it as a place for tourists to visit, as well as renting horses.\xc2\xa0Manson\xc2\xa0took a liking to the property, and eventually worked out a deal with\xc2\xa0Spahn, under which the Family could live there rent-free, provided\xc2\xa0Spahn, who was going blind, and the ranch would be taken care of.\xc2\xa0In Oxygen\xe2\x80\x99s upcoming documentary special, \xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women,\xe2\x80\x9d former Family members described their early days on the\xc2\xa0Spahn\xc2\xa0Ranch as pastoral and almost utopian.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cSitting around the ranch front, drinking coffee, watching the parade of wranglers and writers, George Spahn taking his daily walk ... chickens clucking, roosters crowing, the old goat, the dog, the horses coming and going with new riders on their backs," former Family member Sandra Good told the producers\xc2\xa0of\xc2\xa0the special.\xc2\xa0The extent to which Family members needed to work on the ranch is not agreed upon \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0some allege the women traded sexual favors with Spahn, who would have been 80 years old in 1969,\xc2\xa0as part of the deal.\xc2\xa0Former Family member Catherine Share,\xc2\xa0who was called Gypsy while she was with the family, told producers of \xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women" that she had no trouble taking care of Spahn, because he reminded her of her own step-father.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cBut I like cooking, and I could take care of George very easily,\xc2\xa0because I was used to taking care of a blind step-father,\xe2\x80\x9d Share said. \xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xc2\xa0I just kind of did what I wanted to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Share added on the show that, to her knowledge, there was no strict requirement for work\xc2\xa0in order for\xc2\xa0the Family to stay on the ranch.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cCharlie never said you have to work,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know,\xc2\xa0it was just common knowledge that everybody there wanted to help as much as they could.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Lynette\xc2\xa0Fromme, dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cSqueaky\xe2\x80\x9d by\xc2\xa0Spahn, disputed rumors that the women were expected to have sex with\xc2\xa0Spahn\xc2\xa0in exchange for staying on the ranch.\xc2\xa0When asked about what people often get wrong about her story, on \xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Fromme\xc2\xa0said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe idea that I was having sex with this old man on the ranch \xe2\x80\xa6 That\xe2\x80\x99s a big one.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Nevertheless, while staying on the ranch, Manson and his followers would\xc2\xa0indulge heavily in LSD and\xc2\xa0free love, according to CNN\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\xaf2017 obituary for Manson.\xe2\x80\xafThese activities would, infamously, escalate to the most brutal murder.\xc2\xa0After the Family\xe2\x80\x99s murders, the most infamous being the death of Roman Polanski\xe2\x80\x99s wife, Sharon Tate, Manson and seven other Family members \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Bobby Beausoleil,\xc2\xa0Tex\xc2\xa0Watson, Leslie Van\xc2\xa0Houten, Patricia\xc2\xa0Krenwinkle, Bruce Davis, and Steve \xe2\x80\x9cClem\xe2\x80\x9d Grogan\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 were\xc2\xa0later\xc2\xa0convicted for the crimes they committed\xc2\xa0in 1971 and 1972. Linda Kasabian was given immunity as a state\xe2\x80\x99s witness. Although\xc2\xa0most family members\xc2\xa0were sentenced to death, California \xe2\x80\xafabolished the death penalty\xc2\xa0in 1972; they were instead converted to \xe2\x80\xaflife sentences\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xafin prison instead.\xe2\x80\xaf\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0In September 1970, the Spahn Ranch burned in a brush fire along with a considerable amount of Chatsworth,\xe2\x80\xafaccording to the \xe2\x80\xafLos Angeles Times. Manson died in 2017 from\xe2\x80\xafcomplications related to\xc2\xa0colon cancer.\xe2\x80\xaf\xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women\xe2\x80\x9d will premiere on Oxygen Aug.\xe2\x80\xaf10\xe2\x80\xafat\xe2\x80\xaf7\xe2\x80\xafp.m. ET/PT.Crime Time is your destination for true crime stories from around the world, breaking crime news, and information about Oxygen\'s original true crime shows and documentaries. Sign up for our Crime Time Newsletter and subscribe to our true crime podcast Martinis & Murder for all the best true crime content.

Costa Rican authorities say tainted liquor is responsible for the recent deaths of 19 people. Since the beginning of June, fourteen men and five women between the ages of 32-72 have lost their lives after drinking contaminated alcohol in the small Central American country.On July 19, the Costa Rican Ministry of Health announced it had confiscated 30,000 bottles of counterfeit alcohol bearing labels from six reputable liquor manufacturers. The identical labels make the contaminated spirits indistinguishable from legitimate products. Authorities discovered lethal amounts of the chemical methanol mixed in bottles labeled Guaro Montano, Guaro Gran Apache, Aguardiente Estrella, Aguardiente Barón Rojo, Aguardiente Timbuka and Molotov Aguardiente. The Ministry of Health has issued a statement alerting the public not to drink these brands until their investigation is completed. They also warned that anyone selling bootleg liquor or any illegal alcohol may face criminal charges. “We deeply regret the lives that have been claimed because of the sale of beverages with liquor adulterated with methanol. I have instructed [the Health Ministry] and other authorities to collect all possible data…” Costa Rica President Carlos Alvarado Quesada tweeted on July 18.The deaths in Costa Rica occurred around the same time as the unexplained deaths of at least 10 American tourists at resorts throughout the Dominican Republic. ABC News reported that unlike the tourists who died in the Dominican Republic, all of the Costa Rican victims were citizens and that none of the spirits were consumed at a hotel. Here’s what you need to know.
\n\nThey believe the cause is methanol poisoning, but the ministry stressed that the information is “preliminary as investigations continue.”https://t.co/3G9Ho7x9Ol— New York Daily News (@NYDailyNews) July 21, 2019Methanol is an industrial alcohol commonly found in antifreeze and solvents. It’s cheaper and easier to manufacture than ethanol, the alcohol found in liquor, beer and wine, but is not meant for human consumption. Drinking a small amount of methanol is potentially fatal. Methanol and other chemicals are sometimes added to increase the volume of illegal alcohol and make drinks more powerful.“When you distill alcohol in an unregulated way, it’s actually quite dangerous,” Nathan Lent a biology expert at John Jay College of Criminal Justice told Vice. — Sky News (@SkyNews) February 9, 2019Most Americans are unaware of the dangers of drinking alcohol abroad thanks to tight U.S. regulations that ensure liquor safety at home. But according to the World Health Organization (WHO), “unreported” alcohol accounts for up to 25% of all alcohol consumed around the world. The International Alliance for Responsible Drinking (IARD) issued a 2018 report outlining the problem of counterfeit alcohol overseas. Tainted spirits are common in developing countries. They account for 19% of the alcohol sales in Costa Rica and 29% in the Dominican Republic. In February 2019, more than 154 people died after drinking homemade booze laced with methanol in India’s northeastern state of Assam. These “homegrown liquors” are typically produced in villages and then sold illegally in cities for about a third of the cost of lawful liquor. “Alcohol produced and sold illegally outside of government regulation is the most problematic part of unrecorded alcohol; it is untaxed, circumvents restrictions around availability, is of inconsistent quality, and, depending on the ingredients used to make it, is even potentially toxic,” the IARD’s report explained. — New York Post (@nypost) June 28, 2019The U.S. Embassy issued a statement on its website announcing that the FBI had sent a team to the Dominican Republic to assist Dominican authorities with toxicology tests.The New York Post reported that the FBI was testing liquor samples from the rooms of the tourists who died as well as blood samples from the deceased. Their findings have not been released. Last June, Senator Chuck Schumer appealed to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) as well as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to step in and assist the FBI with the investigation. “ATF & more CDC experts should help the FBI with fact-finding. Now,” he tweeted.— CTSSA (@CTSSA) June 19, 2019Initial methanol poisoning replicates the same symptoms of drunkenness: dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. Extreme methanol poisoning can lead to seizures and unconsciousness. Drinking just two to eight ounces can lead to lead to death.The CDC noted that methanol’s effects can take up to 72 hours to appear. According to Medline, permanent blindness can occur after drinking methanol.— Gregory Meriweather (@MeriAssociates) July 22, 2019Lent suggested taking a small amount of liquor and lighting it on fire. The flame will burn green or orange if the spirits contain methanol, and blue if the liquor is pure. “Anything that doesn’t burn blue is a cause for concern,” Lent noted. Lent said tourists should smell their liquor before imbibing since contaminated drinks may have an unusual odor. He also recommended that travelers steer away from clear alcohol, which is easy for bootleggers to replicate. Doing without alcohol in countries where bootleg liquor is a problem may be the safest option. “Tainted drinks are a real threat for vacationers,” Dr. Manny Alvarez wrote in a piece for Fox News.

For me the old DJI Phantom 3 Advanced drone was a try-out. I got it from a friend who switched to a newer model. Although the quality isn't that good for photography, I definitely got an idea of what was possibleOne of the first photos I took with a drone; a panorama of a nearby lake. Photographing with a drone is completely different and it can be difficult to find a good composition. (DJI Phantom 3 Advanced ISO100 f/2,8 1/200 - panorama from 3 images)The winding route of small brook. It almost looks like a miniature Amazon river. (DJI MAvic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/5 stack of 5 images)The same brook from the previous image, just from a few meters high. Although it does not look like a drone photo at first sight, this photo is not possible without it. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/160 panorama from 3 shots)This pond cannot be reached on foot because there is a ditch, trees, and bushes that prevent a good photo. But with the drone it is no problem. Just a few meters high, not more that thirty meter further. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/20 stack of 5 shots)The wonderful waterfall called Fossurin \xc3\xad Foss\xc3\xa1 at the Faroe Islands. The drone made it possible to take a much higher vantage point. I had to make a panorama to make the field of view large enough (DJI MAvic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/80 panorama from 8 shots)
I have been photographing this beautiful waterfall called Cascade de la Beaume many times, but never from this point of view. It is a great addition to all the other photos I have. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/5 Kase ND16)The planes of the Faroe Islands during sunset, looking towards Sl\xc3\xa6ttaratindur. The higher vantage point show a completely different landscape than from below. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/60)I did not know of these ponds in a nearby moorland, until I noticed it while flying the drone. Just twenty meters from the footpath, and not more than two meters high made it possible to shoot this sunset. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/8 Panorama from 3 shots)These ponds in the moorland are almost impossible to photograph; you cannot reach it. But with the drone it is possible. Again, only from a few meters high to keep a normal perspective (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/400 panorama from 3 shots)Nando Harmsen is a Dutch photographer that is specialized in wedding and landscape photography. With his roots in the analog photo age he gained an extensive knowledge about photography techniques and equipment, and shares this through his personal blog and many workshops.For anyone using a drone, there is an excellent app called AirMap. It will help you to avoid no-fly zones in North America, perhaps elsewhere also.I use the app Drone Buddy. Works worldwide and is quite accurate concerning no-fly zonesWhen drones first came out, I thought about getting one for my industrial photography and I may yet do that but, having experienced their use on public lands, I would never get one for any other use. I liken them to your car's stereo: you like the music and think you're cool as you drive down the road, blaring it out your open windows but nobody else is into it. No, they're not as quiet as you think. Yes, they annoy everyone else.

column4: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Tucked away behind trees off of Erda\xe2\x80\x99s Droubay road sits the Flying M Clydesdales Motel, a horse motel run by Alyssa Coombs and her mother, Mickey Falkner.\xc2\xa0The mother-daughter duo originally collaborated to make a successful run at horse competitions and have now opened a business, the first of its kind in Tooele County.\xc2\xa0In 1995, Falkner decided she wanted to raise her twin daughters, Alyssa and Shelley, on a farm instead of in Salt Lake City. Never having been to Tooele County before, Falkner saw an ad in the newspaper for six and a half acres that came with animals.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThe land was pretty bare, but as soon as we got here, we just knew this is where we should be,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt came with a horse, rabbit, dog, and too many cats to count,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs added.It took the move to Erda for Falkner to discover her interest in horses, even though she had grown up on a farm in Iowa. But the breed she became interested in is not your common riding horse \xe2\x80\x94 the tall Clydesdale.\xc2\xa0The twin girls grew up trying a little bit of everything, from rodeo to English riding, but the family didn\xe2\x80\x99t get into driving Clydesdales until Alyssa had left for college.\xc2\xa0Falkner had a friend help teach her to drive her feisty Clydesdale. After Coombs moved back home, they started to show their horses at different competitions.\xc2\xa0Their first horse passed away but now they own two Clydesdales: Strutt and Annabelle. After taking them to Wisconsin last year, Falkner decided to look into starting a horse motel since they had used one on their drive to and from Wisconsin.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHorse motels have been very popular for a number of years for all those traveling state to state for horse shows, buying and selling horses and other trips,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are quite unheard of by the general public, though. We are virtually an AirBnB for anyone traveling with their large animals.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The cost per animal is $20 a night. There is no lodging for owners, but they are welcome to stay in their trailer on the property.\xc2\xa0The horses are required to be in good health and have vaccination papers. Yet at no time are Falkner\xe2\x80\x99s and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 horses allowed to go nose to nose with visiting horses.\xc2\xa0Their horse motel is the only one within hours of Salt Lake City.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cA professional horse shipper just said she is thrilled there is now a horse motel in our county,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s great for show season, or buying or selling. A lot of people are having horses shipped state to state.\xe2\x80\x9dEvery stall comes with fresh bedding, but each customer needs to bring their own feed and water buckets.\xc2\xa0Their first guest horse traveled from Hawaii.This year they were invited to escort the Grand Marshal and his grandchildren at the Bit n\xe2\x80\x99 Spur Rodeo held at Desert Peak Complex during the July 3 and July 4 shows.\xc2\xa0Clydesdale horses don\xe2\x80\x99t rodeo, but have their own shows. Last October, Falkner and Coombs drove to Madison, Wisconsin, where they participated in the World Clydesdale Show.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt definitely takes a team,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said about what she has learned from participating and supporting her mom.\xc2\xa0Many people are needed to help assist in getting all the equipment, horses and everything prepared for a show. People will often hire help.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a really high equipment sport where you have to bring feed, harnesses, vehicles, cleaning equipment, rakes, brooms, and more to every event,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said.\xc2\xa0At the shows families rent out stalls for their horses, a stall for equipment, one for their own personal use \xe2\x80\x94 and sometimes even more stalls.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cEveryone works so well together,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe share a lot and are willing to help other families out if their child needs something to enter a competition.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0In Montana, Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 son, Declan, participated with her in the Pleasure Driving category where they took second place. That day it was windy and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 hat kept trying to blow away, so she had to hold it with one hand and try driving at the same time. They lost to their friend\xe2\x80\x99s mares, whom Coombs claims are the best.\xc2\xa0Next year they plan on letting Declan participate. Her youngest son Quinn, age 5, already loves being around the horses and Coombs trusts the Clydesdales more than a standard-sized horse, especially since Strutt and Annabelle are so easy going.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI love their personalities,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re super cool and sensible.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0One of the competitions they enter Strutt in is the obstacle course.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of tight turns and it\xe2\x80\x99s a speed event,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0Participants aren\xe2\x80\x99t given a trial course beforehand but a piece of paper that shows where the obstacles are. \xc2\xa0At the Wisconsin show, Coombs won the costume competition, beating out 40 entries. Coombs, an accomplished seamstress, had sewn her horse Strutt and herself skeleton costumes.When Coombs is not helping out with the horses she can be found sewing. A customer in Grantsville hired her to sew a three-piece suit for her horse to wear for their family pictures. There are no patterns for horses.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI had to go do fittings and come up with it out of my head,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cI got all of this scrap fabric all over the horse and then made cuts. We\xe2\x80\x99re all excited to see how the pictures turn out.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0For the last three Aprils, Falkner has hosted a clinic at Desert Peak to teach how to drive horses. A seven times world champion has participated and taught the students to drive better. Participants have come from as far as Colorado, Wyoming and Montana.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDraft horse people are genuinely very nice and open to teaching and welcoming,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey want more people to be involved.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Looking back on their experiences, Falkner and Coombs see that it takes teamwork to drive horses and now run a business. Together they make a pretty great team.Check out Flying M Clydesdales Horse Motel on Facebook.

HOLYOKE \xe2\x80\x94 It\xe2\x80\x99s official: U.S. Rep. Richard Neal, D-Springfield, has a 2020 challenger for his seat in the 1st Congressional District.After months of speculation about his political plans, Holyoke Mayor Alex Morse officially jumped into the race on Monday. He will take on Neal, who has been in Congress since 1989, when Democratic primary voters head to the polls on Sept. 15, 2020.\xe2\x80\x9cI think there\xe2\x80\x99s an urgency to this moment that isn\xe2\x80\x99t matched by our current representative in Congress,\xe2\x80\x9d Morse said Monday morning.When Morse, 30, was first sworn in as mayor of his hometown of Holyoke in 2012, he was both the youngest-ever mayor in the city at 22 and its first openly gay mayor. Born to working-class parents who met in one of Holyoke\xe2\x80\x99s public housing projects, Morse was the first person in his family to graduate from college. He was a senior at Brown University when he first announced his mayoral candidacy.Neal, 70, is one of the most influential members of Congress, where he chairs the powerful Ways and Means Committee that writes tax law. He has held his seat for 30 years, making him the dean of the Massachusetts delegation to the U.S. House. Before serving in Congress, he served as a city councilor and later as mayor in Springfield.Neal\xe2\x80\x99s campaign manager, Peter Panos, said that the congressman was not available for an interview on Monday, though he did issue a statement on behalf of Neal\xe2\x80\x99s campaign.\xe2\x80\x9cWe are fortunate to live in a country where everyone can have his or her voice heard by running for office, and that\xe2\x80\x99s why Congressman Neal will welcome anyone into this race,\xe2\x80\x9d the statement reads. \xe2\x80\x9cRichie has been a champion for working families in western Massachusetts and has fought tirelessly to ensure that the people of our region are not forgotten and receive our fair share.\xe2\x80\x9d On his campaign website, Morse touted his efforts leading an \xe2\x80\x9ceconomic rebirth\xe2\x80\x9d in Holyoke, his work on the issue of affordable housing, his defense of reproductive rights, community policing initiatives and a needle exchange program he helped implement in the city. Morse said he seeks to distinguish himself from what he described as the \xe2\x80\x9cstatus quo\xe2\x80\x9d represented by Neal, which he said the district can no longer afford to support. He said that unlike Neal, he supports progressive policies like the Green New Deal and Medicare for All. There is a significant generational gap between the two candidates, with 40 years separating them in age. Morse said that his youth gives him a different way of looking at how government can work.\xe2\x80\x9cCongressman Neal certainly knows how Washington works, and I want to change how Washington works,\xe2\x80\x9d Morse said. He added that the district doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need just any Democrat, but one that will push for bold policies. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter serving 30 years in the position, you become resigned to these low expectations of what government can do for people.\xe2\x80\x9d Morse has announced that he will not accept corporate PAC money, instead relying on grassroots funding from individual donors. He contrasted that approach with Neal, who is one of the top recipients of corporate PAC money in Congress, including significant contributions from the health insurance and pharmaceutical industries.\xe2\x80\x9cWe have people that are struggling to get health insurance in western Massachusetts,\xe2\x80\x9d Morse said. \xe2\x80\x9cThose that have health insurance are often underinsured. ... It\xe2\x80\x99s important that we have a member of Congress that puts people before pharmaceutical industry profits.\xe2\x80\x9d As a top fundraiser in the party, Neal\xe2\x80\x99s campaign committee is sitting on almost $4 million in cash on hand. In 2018, Neal defeated progressive challenger Tahirah Amatul-Wadud in the district\xe2\x80\x99s Democratic primary, heavily outspending Amatul-Wadud and winning around 70 percent of the vote.Morse\xe2\x80\x99s campaign said that he hopes to raise $1 million in 2019, and an additional $2 million in 2020.Morse said that he plans to knock on doors across the 1st District. He said that to defeat Neal, his campaign will have to \xe2\x80\x9cexpand the universe\xe2\x80\x9d of primary voters by turning out residents of the district who might otherwise sit out a primary election.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re going to run a different kind of campaign \xe2\x80\x94 a campaign that I don\xe2\x80\x99t think this district has seen,\xe2\x80\x9d Morse said. That\xe2\x80\x99s one of the main reasons he has announced his campaign around 14 months ahead of election day, he added.Morse said he has reached out to local elected officials, community leaders and activists to let them know of his plans to run. But he stressed that it is not the support of elected officials that he is focused on.\xe2\x80\x9cThis campaign will not be won with endorsements from elected officials or national groups,\xe2\x80\x9d Morse said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe most important endorsement we can get is from the people of the district.\xe2\x80\x9d The sprawling 1st District consists of 87 communities in five counties, including the Franklin County municipalities of Ashfield, Bernardston, Buckland, Colrain, Conway, Charlemont, Hawley, Heath, Leyden, Monroe, Rowe and Shelburne. Tucked away behind trees off of Erda\xe2\x80\x99s Droubay road sits the Flying M Clydesdales Motel, a horse motel run by Alyssa Coombs and her mother, Mickey Falkner.\xc2\xa0The mother-daughter duo originally collaborated to make a successful run at horse competitions and have now opened a business, the first of its kind in Tooele County.\xc2\xa0In 1995, Falkner decided she wanted to raise her twin daughters, Alyssa and Shelley, on a farm instead of in Salt Lake City. Never having been to Tooele County before, Falkner saw an ad in the newspaper for six and a half acres that came with animals.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThe land was pretty bare, but as soon as we got here, we just knew this is where we should be,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt came with a horse, rabbit, dog, and too many cats to count,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs added.It took the move to Erda for Falkner to discover her interest in horses, even though she had grown up on a farm in Iowa. But the breed she became interested in is not your common riding horse \xe2\x80\x94 the tall Clydesdale.\xc2\xa0The twin girls grew up trying a little bit of everything, from rodeo to English riding, but the family didn\xe2\x80\x99t get into driving Clydesdales until Alyssa had left for college.\xc2\xa0Falkner had a friend help teach her to drive her feisty Clydesdale. After Coombs moved back home, they started to show their horses at different competitions.\xc2\xa0Their first horse passed away but now they own two Clydesdales: Strutt and Annabelle. After taking them to Wisconsin last year, Falkner decided to look into starting a horse motel since they had used one on their drive to and from Wisconsin.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHorse motels have been very popular for a number of years for all those traveling state to state for horse shows, buying and selling horses and other trips,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are quite unheard of by the general public, though. We are virtually an AirBnB for anyone traveling with their large animals.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The cost per animal is $20 a night. There is no lodging for owners, but they are welcome to stay in their trailer on the property.\xc2\xa0The horses are required to be in good health and have vaccination papers. Yet at no time are Falkner\xe2\x80\x99s and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 horses allowed to go nose to nose with visiting horses.\xc2\xa0Their horse motel is the only one within hours of Salt Lake City.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cA professional horse shipper just said she is thrilled there is now a horse motel in our county,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s great for show season, or buying or selling. A lot of people are having horses shipped state to state.\xe2\x80\x9dEvery stall comes with fresh bedding, but each customer needs to bring their own feed and water buckets.\xc2\xa0Their first guest horse traveled from Hawaii.This year they were invited to escort the Grand Marshal and his grandchildren at the Bit n\xe2\x80\x99 Spur Rodeo held at Desert Peak Complex during the July 3 and July 4 shows.\xc2\xa0Clydesdale horses don\xe2\x80\x99t rodeo, but have their own shows. Last October, Falkner and Coombs drove to Madison, Wisconsin, where they participated in the World Clydesdale Show.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt definitely takes a team,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said about what she has learned from participating and supporting her mom.\xc2\xa0Many people are needed to help assist in getting all the equipment, horses and everything prepared for a show. People will often hire help.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a really high equipment sport where you have to bring feed, harnesses, vehicles, cleaning equipment, rakes, brooms, and more to every event,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said.\xc2\xa0At the shows families rent out stalls for their horses, a stall for equipment, one for their own personal use \xe2\x80\x94 and sometimes even more stalls.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cEveryone works so well together,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe share a lot and are willing to help other families out if their child needs something to enter a competition.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0In Montana, Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 son, Declan, participated with her in the Pleasure Driving category where they took second place. That day it was windy and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 hat kept trying to blow away, so she had to hold it with one hand and try driving at the same time. They lost to their friend\xe2\x80\x99s mares, whom Coombs claims are the best.\xc2\xa0Next year they plan on letting Declan participate. Her youngest son Quinn, age 5, already loves being around the horses and Coombs trusts the Clydesdales more than a standard-sized horse, especially since Strutt and Annabelle are so easy going.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI love their personalities,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re super cool and sensible.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0One of the competitions they enter Strutt in is the obstacle course.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of tight turns and it\xe2\x80\x99s a speed event,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0Participants aren\xe2\x80\x99t given a trial course beforehand but a piece of paper that shows where the obstacles are. \xc2\xa0At the Wisconsin show, Coombs won the costume competition, beating out 40 entries. Coombs, an accomplished seamstress, had sewn her horse Strutt and herself skeleton costumes.When Coombs is not helping out with the horses she can be found sewing. A customer in Grantsville hired her to sew a three-piece suit for her horse to wear for their family pictures. There are no patterns for horses.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI had to go do fittings and come up with it out of my head,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cI got all of this scrap fabric all over the horse and then made cuts. We\xe2\x80\x99re all excited to see how the pictures turn out.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0For the last three Aprils, Falkner has hosted a clinic at Desert Peak to teach how to drive horses. A seven times world champion has participated and taught the students to drive better. Participants have come from as far as Colorado, Wyoming and Montana.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDraft horse people are genuinely very nice and open to teaching and welcoming,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey want more people to be involved.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Looking back on their experiences, Falkner and Coombs see that it takes teamwork to drive horses and now run a business. Together they make a pretty great team.Check out Flying M Clydesdales Horse Motel on Facebook.

column4: Mainland High School, Florida, United States
column5:
At a School Board meeting that otherwise may not have addressed the topic, Volusia United Educators President Elizabeth Albert asked School Board members to confront the elephant in the room: what happened at Mainland High School.Albert asked board members for an apology for teachers who came forward with concerns about the school's plan to give the majority of the school's freshmen a placebo Advanced Placement exam, instead of the legitimate one that would give them college credit if they passed. Instead, 336 students took a fake exam and believed it was the real thing, until news of the plan broke in June.Principal of the Daytona Beach high school Cheryl Salerno was reprimanded along with former Chief Academic Officer Teresa Marcks.[READ MORE: Volusia County school officials reprimanded for placebo AP exams at Mainland High][READ MORE: 'Placebo' test means no college credit for 336 Mainland AP students]The district finished its investigation into an anonymous complaint sent to the Florida Department of Education in June, and on July 15 released its verdict: that Salerno and Marcks had violated professional conduct standards.Since then, the district's top leaders have said little.In a release on July 15, Superintendent Tim Egnor said the decision not to give every student the official test, and to keep them in the dark, \"cannot be justified, and must be addressed.\"School Board Chairman Carl Persis was interviewed repeatedly about the investigation, and said he was \"deeply troubled\" by what the students experienced.And School Board member Ruben Colon called it \"fraud\" and \"a disruption.\"Albert wanted more.\"I never heard an apology to the teachers, the parents and the community,\" she said. \"Will you say today, publicly to these teachers, 'You did no wrong. You were following the directives of your supervisor. We're sorry we didn't listen to you.' \"She explained that one of her biggest concerns is hearing that students and parents will struggle now to trust their teachers — something now-sophomore Molly Reilly who took the course last year and was given a placebo exam said.\"I can't trust what (teachers) say,\" she told The News-Journal. \"You'd think (school) would be a very honest, safe place. Now it just seems fake and untrustworthy.\"[READ MORE: Scores soon available to Mainland students who took official AP exam over 'placebo'][READ MORE: Waiting for more details about 'placebo' AP tests, Mainland families feel deceived]Albert called this comment \"devastating,\" and emphasized that the three AP Seminar teachers at the school voiced concerns about the course and its implementation as early as last summer, but were directed to proceed anyway, and not to tell students they wouldn't all take the real test.\"The teachers were brave and bold and came forward and had articulated their concern from the beginning, but nobody listened,\" Albert said. She asked board members to publicly support them.At the end of the meeting, School Board member Ida Wright reaffirmed her support for the school.\"As an alumni of Mainland High I love Mainland, I support the teachers, parents, students and alumni,\" she said, quickly echoed by Jamie Haynes and Ruben Colon.Linda Cuthbert spoke in the same vein.\"A lot of things happen that are extremely good at Mainland High School,\" she said. \"I think you can go into any public school, anywhere, and there's going to be controversy. So we have to be supportive of the employees.\"And Persis pointed out that he has said multiple times he supports the teachers, but it doesn't always make it into the news coverage.Then the meeting adjourned.Since the conclusion of the investigation, Mainland Assistant Principal Robert Voges was transferred to another school. So was AP Seminar teacher Jason Kester. Salerno and AP Seminar teachers Vita Gaines and Mark Convoy remain at Mainland.[ALSO AT THE MEETING: Volusia School Board sets higher pay range in superintendent search][ALSO AT THE MEETING: Volusia School Board loosens uniform rules for high schoolers]

At a School Board meeting that otherwise may not have addressed the topic, Volusia United Educators President Elizabeth Albert asked School Board members to confront the elephant in the room: what happened at Mainland High School.Albert asked board members for an apology for teachers who came forward with concerns about the school’s plan to give the majority of the school’s freshmen a placebo Advanced Placement exam, instead of the legitimate one that would give them college credit if they passed. You were following the directives of your supervisor. We’re sorry we didn’t listen to you.’ ”She explained that one of her biggest concerns is hearing that students and parents will struggle now to trust their teachers — something now-sophomore Molly Reilly who took the course last year and was given a placebo exam said.“I can’t trust what (teachers) say,” she told The News-Journal. “You’d think (school) would be a very honest, safe place. Now it just seems fake and untrustworthy.”[READ MORE: Scores soon available to Mainland students who took official AP exam over 'placebo'][READ MORE: Waiting for more details about 'placebo' AP tests, Mainland families feel deceived]Albert called this comment “devastating,” and emphasized that the three AP Seminar teachers at the school voiced concerns about the course and its implementation as early as last summer, but were directed to proceed anyway, and not to tell students they wouldn’t all take the real test.“The teachers were brave and bold and came forward and had articulated their concern from the beginning, but nobody listened,” Albert said. She asked board members to publicly support them.At the end of the meeting, School Board member Ida Wright reaffirmed her support for the school.“As an alumni of Mainland High I love Mainland, I support the teachers, parents, students and alumni,” she said, quickly echoed by Jamie Haynes and Ruben Colon.Linda Cuthbert spoke in the same vein.“A lot of things happen that are extremely good at Mainland HIgh School,” she said. “I think you can go into any public school, anywhere, and there’s going to be controversy. So we have to be supportive of the employees.”And Persis pointed out that he has said multiple times he supports the teachers, but it doesn’t always make it into the news coverage.Then the meeting adjourned.Since the conclusion of the investigation, Mainland Assistant Principal Robert Voges was transferred to another school. So was AP Seminar teacher Jason Kester. Salerno and AP Seminar teachers Vita Gaines and Mark Convoy remain at Mainland.[ALSO AT THE MEETING: Volusia School Board sets higher pay range in superintendent search][ALSO AT THE MEETING: Volusia School Board loosens uniform rules for high schoolers] Choose the plan that's right for you.

column4: North Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, United Kingdom
column5: Fans have been waiting since 2018 when several races had to been cancelled after the track did not meet strict safety requirements.READ MORE: Boris Johnson is a "worthy winner" says Scarborough and Whitby MP Robert GoodwillThe new organisers, Two Four Three Road Racing Association — a motorcycle club formed earlier this year — have spent over \xc2\xa3100,000 to improve safety for the public, riders and marshals. Staff and volunteers have worked tirelessly to bring the famous track back to life. The Barry Sheene Classic includes more than 21 races over Saturday and Sunday and star-studded parades on both days with four-time world champion Carl Fogarty leading one parade.Barry Sheene made his debut in Scarborough in 1970 during which he scored a record-breaking victory in the 125cc race.In total he won a 15 races at Oliver’s Mount and the Classic was created in his name after his passing in 2003.Star riders including TT winners Dean Harrison — who holds the circuit lap record — and Lee Johnston are taking part this weekend. It was announced in March that racing was being brought back to Scarborough with the full backing of Scarborough Council, who granted a lease to GrantRoberts Ltd to operate at Oliver’s Mount as Two Four Three Road Racing Association.The 2.43 mile track is the only English road racing circuit and is a favourite amongst both UK and international fans and riders.READ MORE: Scarborough businesses urged to take steps to combat sea pollutionThe company has a wealth of experience in the sport from former Grand Prix and Isle Of Man TT racer, Eddie Roberts, and seven times TT winner and multiple winner at Oliver’s Mount, Mick Grant.Mr Grant said: “I watched my first road race at Oliver’s Mount in short pants back in the early ‘50s and it ignited my passion for racing; we couldn’t let this historic track crumble into the history books. “We need road racing in England; it’s one of the finest tracks in the world and it’s unique. I can’t wait to hear and witness classic and modern bikes race around this demanding track once again.”The track at Oliver’s Mount has been at the heart of motorcycle racing for more than 70 years with the circuit hosting its first race in 1946. The narrow and twisty circuit, with its hairpin corners and short straights, has challenged a multitude of racing stars throughout the decades including John Surtees, Giacomo Agostini, Barry Sheene and Carl Fogarty. Throughout its history, Oliver’s Mount has regularly attracted record crowds that thrive on its thrilling atmosphere and close proximity to the racing action.The next race is the Gold Cup which takes place on September 28 and 29.

Debbie-Joy AgeeDebbie-Joy Agee and Karen Tilbury Debbie-Joy Agee, 60, was born at Warrington Hospital in 1959, one year after her parents met while her dad was based at Burtonwood Airbase. The couple, Joy and Bill, had married before she was born and moved to Arpley Street in the town centre before leaving the country for America in 1960. Debbie-Joy and her parents before moving to America Debbie-Joy has longed to return to the place where her parents met, and her wish was granted by her cousin, Karen Tilbury, who planned a special trip for her. Karen explained: "The day was just perfect and we visited areas of interest, such as the casino where Debbie-Joy's mum and dad first met, the first time she had returned to Arpley Street since leaving just before the age of one and Warrington Hospital where she was born. "We also visited RAF Burtonwood Heritage Centre, where I had pre-arranged a wedding photo of her mum and dad to be framed and hung on the wall at the chapel. Debbie-Joy visiting the street where she once lived "Meeting the mayor for tea and a guided tour around the town hall was a complete surprise for both Debbie-Joy and her husband, Montie, and certainly completed their day, leaving them with exceptional memories of Warrington and, of course, the typical weather- a day full of rain. "I would personally like to thank the mayor and the staff at the Democratic Services for making this reunion very memorable." With the help of Warrington Hospital, Karen has managed to trace Debbie-Joy's birth records, meaning she will now be able to obtain them. Debbie-Joy with the documents she needs to obtain her birth certificate Debbie-Joy said: "My experience in Warrington was one I shall never forget. "After 60 years away, it all came together seeing the places where my parents met, the hospital where I was born and eventually the place were we lived before coming to the United States. "The visit with the mayor and her staff, and a trip to the Burtonwood Museum made it all the more special. Debbie-Joy and Warrington Mayor Wendy Johnson "I never had the feeling I was a visitor in Warrington, or anywhere during our two-week journey through the UK, but in fact felt it was truly my other home." 60 YEARS AGOFriday, November 21, 1947THE LIGHT THAT FAILED: On Wednesday night the electricity supply was turned off in parts of the town, a cut having been ordered by the Central Electricity Board owing to the load having become too heavy for the Grid. A cut of 10 per cent on the voltage had already been affected, but not proved enough. PHENOMENAL WEATHER: Not for many a year has this part of the country experienced such severe wintry weather in November as that of this week. The cold spell started on Friday morning when six degrees were registered at Messrs Forbes\' Nurseries. At the same place eight degrees were registered on Saturday morning, 11 on Sunday, 15 on Monday, 23 on Tuesday, 26 on Wednesday and nine yesterday. On Wednesday the Teviot was frozen over above the Cobble Cauld.PRINGLE\'S AT THE PALACE: At the party on Tuesday afternoon given by Their Majesties at St James\' Palace for specially invited guests to view the wedding presents which were received from all over the world by Princecss Elizabeth and Lieutenant Mountbatten, Robert Pringle & Son Ltd, who received an invitation, were represented by Mr G. G. Sinclair, their London manager and Mr W. R. T. Rodger, publicity manager from their London office.They spent two hours at the Palace viewing the presents, where they met various Court personalities and were complimented by several on the beauty and workmanship of the \'Pringle\' Cashmere Sets. The gifts from \'Pringle of Scotland\' were amongst those displayed on the centre table in the Grand Hall of St James\' Palace.HONOUR FOR TYPIST: Seventeen-year-old Miss Joyce Huggan, a junior typist of Robert Pringle & Son Ltd, who was selected to represent the Rangers of the County of Roxburgh in the Guard of Honour at the wedding of Princess Elizabeth, left Hawick on Wednesday morning to travel to London. The position allocated to the Company of Rangers with whom Miss Huggan travelled was within the Main Gates of Buckingham Palace. She has three years\' service with the Rangers and is a member of the 2nd Hawick Company.40 YEARS AGOFriday, November 24, 1967COMMANDO RECRUIT: Stuart Morgan (21), 64 Weensland Road, is giving up his job as a teller at Hawick Savings Bank to train as a Commando with the Royal Marines. A former pupil of Hawick High School and an employee of the Bank for the past three years, he begins his "new life" next month when he reports to Deal, Kent.PRISON OFFICER: Mr Lindsay McColm, 8 Melgund Place, a frame worker with Peter Scott & Co., leaves Hawick on December 11 to train as a prison officer at Durham jail.STUDENT\'S SUCCESS: Mr Colin Watson, 3 Wellington Street, an employee at the Peter Scott & Co. factory, received his ATI (Associate of the Textile Institute) diploma at a ceremony in Manchester on Friday.DEATH OF TWEED MANUFACTURER: Mr John Scoon, a former Hawick tweed manufacturer who was managing director of the old-established firm of Scoon & Hood, died at his home, Gowanlea, East Stewart Place, on Sunday, aged 75.LEGION ON FORM: Legion deservedly beat Gala Rovers 2-1 in a Border Amateur League game at Netherdale on Saturday. The score does an injustice to the Hawick side who were much the superior team and should have won more convincingly.Rovers went ahead in the 6th minute through Lumsden whose shot beat the outrushing Fletcher. Legion were not long in arrears, a good  move down the left ending with Malcolm Boyd cutting a good ball back from the bye-line for I. Turnbull to stab the ball past Tancock.Legion kept the upper hand in the second half and, with 10 minutes left to play, the ball was cleared up field to Malcolm Boyd and the big centre ran on to lash a glorious shot past Tancock. The Rovers never recovered and Legion were still on the offensive at the final whistle.20 YEARS AGOFriday, November 27, 1987ACCIDENT TO BUTCHER: Ex-Cornet Donald Lunn was detained in Peel Hospital when he had stitches inserted in a finger wound accidentally sustained in his butcher\'s shop in Howegate on Tuesday when he was working with a carving knife.NEW CHURCH: Following a meeting of members of St George\'s West Church and the former St Margaret\'s and Wilton South Church held in St George\'s West on Sunday, it was agreed to accept the Unions of the two congregations under the new name of Hawick Teviot Parish Church. The Rev. Neil Combe will continue as minister.TV APPEARANCE: Mrs Theresa Swanson, 17 Daykins Drive, was invited to London at the weekend to take part in Noel Edmonds\' BBC1 show, Whatever Next?, with her brother-in-law Robert Smith, who lives in Sussex. Mrs Swanson was treated to a night in the Kensington Palace Hotel.The show will be broadcast on December 22 as part of a Christmas special.PRINGLE RUMOURS DENIED: Rumours circulating in the town that Pringle of Scotland may be renamed Pringle International, with the bulk of production switched to Berwick or elsewhere, have been denied by Mr E. Mitchell, personnel director.He said on Wednesday that there was no foundation in the suggestions and added that the company were currently investing 600,000 in new knitting machinery for Glebe Mill.SUPPORTERS\' CLUB: The first meeting of the Steven Hislop Supporters\' Club was held in the Fox & Hounds, Denholm, on Friday, chaired by Hamish Smith, when over 70 members attended. The group was formed recently to provide financial assistance to Ancrum-based motorcycle ace Steven Hislop, winner of this year\'s Isle of Man TT. Items discussed included fund-raising events and a ceilidh.

Live Now: CTV News Channel Ninety per cent of federal carbon tax revenues generated in Manitoba and other provinces will go back to individuals through rebates. (File image). Josh Crabb, Reporter Five million dollars in carbon tax revenue initially earmarked for green projects at Manitoba schools will be redirected to municipalities, universities, or hospitals, according to the federal government. Last week Manitoba Premier Brian Pallister said the province wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t work with Ottawa to distribute the money because he saw the move as a public relations exercise to promote the carbon tax. A spokesperson for Environment Minister Catherine McKenna said that money will now flow to other entities. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the coming weeks we will be releasing details of how the money will be redirected to help Manitoba\xe2\x80\x99s municipalities, universities, or hospitals fight climate change and save money on energy efficiency,\xe2\x80\x9d said spokesperson Bronwen Jervis in an email to CTV Winnipeg. \xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately, there appears to be no precedent of the federal government providing funding to school boards without coordinating with the provincial government.\xe2\x80\x9d McKenna announced late last month $60 million of the revenue from the federal carbon tax will go to elementary and secondary schools in New Brunswick, Ontario, Manitoba and Saskatchewan \xe2\x80\x93 four provinces where the tax has taken effect because they do not have carbon-pricing systems of their own that meet rules laid out by the federal government. Ninety per cent of federal carbon tax revenues generated in Manitoba and other provinces will go back to individuals through rebates. The remaining 10 per cent is earmarked for schools, hospitals, small businesses and other institutions. Jervis said the three other provinces where the federal carbon tax has taken effect have agreed to work with Ottawa to distribute the revenue to schools. \xe2\x80\x9cWe had hoped the province would work with our government to provide these funds to Manitoba\xe2\x80\x99s schools, to help them be better equipped to fight climate change--we\xe2\x80\x99ve all seen students and kids marching in the street, worried about what climate change will mean for their future,\xe2\x80\x9d Jervis wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate that Premier Pallister is standing in the way of funding that would benefit students and teachers in his province. \xe2\x80\x9cOntario, Saskatchewan, and New Brunswick have said they will work with us to provide their portion of the pollution pricing funding for schools.\xe2\x80\x9d In a statement, a spokesperson for Sustainable Development Minister Rochelle Squires called this a "rushed, pre-election stunt from Ottawa to reimburse a tiny portion of the rising federal carbon tax that should never have been taken from Manitobans in the first place. "Instead of hastily dropping these attempted distractions the federal government should recognize the massive investments Manitobans have already made in clean, green energy sources and acknowledge our unique ability to reduce greenhouse gas emissions here and beyond our borders." The spokesperson said McKenna and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau should respect the Made-in-Manitoba Climate and Green Plan and support the action that's taking place in the province.   Two teenagers who are suspects in three murders in British Columbia could be in Manitoba, according to the RCMP.
