\n

Spahn\xe2\x80\xaf Ranch housed Charles Manson and his family at the time they \xe2\x80\xafwere \xe2\x80\xafcommitting brutal murders.\xe2\x80\xafCharles Manson\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xafis infamous for leading the\xc2\xa0cult that brutally\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0killed\xc2\xa0nine\xc2\xa0people\xe2\x80\xafwithin five weeks\xe2\x80\xaf \xe2\x80\x94 one victim was actress\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0Sharon Tate, who was eight months pregnant when she was \xe2\x80\xafmurdered.\xe2\x80\xaf\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0Before the carnage began, however, the Family lived together as an almost stereotypical 1960s-era hippie commune, making their home at a ranch with a rich history in Hollywood Westerns.\xc2\xa0Spahn Ranch was a sprawling \xe2\x80\xafLos Angeles County property\xc2\xa0in the valley, at which a number of Western television shows and movies \xe2\x80\x94 including \xe2\x80\x9cBonanza,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lone Ranger,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIsis\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 were filmed. \xe2\x80\xafGeorge Spahn purchased the property in 1953, and as the Western genre waned in popularity, so would the demand to use the site.\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0Spahn\xc2\xa0was in need of\xc2\xa0a way to make money: He started to diversify by using it as a place for tourists to visit, as well as renting horses.\xc2\xa0Manson\xc2\xa0took a liking to the property, and eventually worked out a deal with\xc2\xa0Spahn, under which the Family could live there rent-free, provided\xc2\xa0Spahn, who was going blind, and the ranch would be taken care of.\xc2\xa0In Oxygen\xe2\x80\x99s upcoming documentary special, \xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women,\xe2\x80\x9d former Family members described their early days on the\xc2\xa0Spahn\xc2\xa0Ranch as pastoral and almost utopian.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cSitting around the ranch front, drinking coffee, watching the parade of wranglers and writers, George Spahn taking his daily walk ... chickens clucking, roosters crowing, the old goat, the dog, the horses coming and going with new riders on their backs," former Family member Sandra Good told the producers\xc2\xa0of\xc2\xa0the special.\xc2\xa0The extent to which Family members needed to work on the ranch is not agreed upon \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0some allege the women traded sexual favors with Spahn, who would have been 80 years old in 1969,\xc2\xa0as part of the deal.\xc2\xa0Former Family member Catherine Share,\xc2\xa0who was called Gypsy while she was with the family, told producers of \xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women" that she had no trouble taking care of Spahn, because he reminded her of her own step-father.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cBut I like cooking, and I could take care of George very easily,\xc2\xa0because I was used to taking care of a blind step-father,\xe2\x80\x9d Share said. \xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xc2\xa0I just kind of did what I wanted to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Share added on the show that, to her knowledge, there was no strict requirement for work\xc2\xa0in order for\xc2\xa0the Family to stay on the ranch.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cCharlie never said you have to work,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know,\xc2\xa0it was just common knowledge that everybody there wanted to help as much as they could.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Lynette\xc2\xa0Fromme, dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cSqueaky\xe2\x80\x9d by\xc2\xa0Spahn, disputed rumors that the women were expected to have sex with\xc2\xa0Spahn\xc2\xa0in exchange for staying on the ranch.\xc2\xa0When asked about what people often get wrong about her story, on \xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Fromme\xc2\xa0said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe idea that I was having sex with this old man on the ranch \xe2\x80\xa6 That\xe2\x80\x99s a big one.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Nevertheless, while staying on the ranch, Manson and his followers would\xc2\xa0indulge heavily in LSD and\xc2\xa0free love, according to CNN\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\xaf2017 obituary for Manson.\xe2\x80\xafThese activities would, infamously, escalate to the most brutal murder.\xc2\xa0After the Family\xe2\x80\x99s murders, the most infamous being the death of Roman Polanski\xe2\x80\x99s wife, Sharon Tate, Manson and seven other Family members \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Bobby Beausoleil,\xc2\xa0Tex\xc2\xa0Watson, Leslie Van\xc2\xa0Houten, Patricia\xc2\xa0Krenwinkle, Bruce Davis, and Steve \xe2\x80\x9cClem\xe2\x80\x9d Grogan\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 were\xc2\xa0later\xc2\xa0convicted for the crimes they committed\xc2\xa0in 1971 and 1972. Linda Kasabian was given immunity as a state\xe2\x80\x99s witness. Although\xc2\xa0most family members\xc2\xa0were sentenced to death, California \xe2\x80\xafabolished the death penalty\xc2\xa0in 1972; they were instead converted to \xe2\x80\xaflife sentences\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xafin prison instead.\xe2\x80\xaf\xe2\x80\xaf\xc2\xa0In September 1970, the Spahn Ranch burned in a brush fire along with a considerable amount of Chatsworth,\xe2\x80\xafaccording to the \xe2\x80\xafLos Angeles Times. Manson died in 2017 from\xe2\x80\xafcomplications related to\xc2\xa0colon cancer.\xe2\x80\xaf\xe2\x80\x9cManson: The Women\xe2\x80\x9d will premiere on Oxygen Aug.\xe2\x80\xaf10\xe2\x80\xafat\xe2\x80\xaf7\xe2\x80\xafp.m. ET/PT.Crime Time is your destination for true crime stories from around the world, breaking crime news, and information about Oxygen\'s original true crime shows and documentaries. Sign up for our Crime Time Newsletter and subscribe to our true crime podcast Martinis & Murder for all the best true crime content.

By Janice Bytheway
Larimer County Dive and Rescue Team, Vice President
Dive 55When you\xe2\x80\x99re a volunteer first responder, there\xe2\x80\x99s no predicting when you\xe2\x80\x99ll get a call, so on Saturday June 29, when Larimer County Dive Rescue Team was paged to respond to a rafter missing on the Poudre River near the Mishawaka, members abandoned their weekend plans to respond (one member even left the chair mid-haircut!). It was not the first time this season LCDRT had been called to the river, and it likely will not be the last, as rivers around Colorado are running high and fast after a cool, wet spring and above-average snowpack. Sadly, the number of people missing or killed on Colorado\xe2\x80\x99s rivers this year has risen into the double digits.\xc2\xa0While swift water season is LCDRT\xe2\x80\x99s most busy time of the year, the team responds to water rescue and recovery calls year round, assisting agencies around the county with ice rescue, dive rescue, and recovery of everything from sunken boats to criminal evidence. The team\xc2\xa0is equipped to respond anywhere in Larimer County, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, and spends one weekend per month training together, plus additional training time in the classroom and pool in order for members to earn the necessary\xc2\xa0certifications.\xc2\xa0In May 2109, LCDRT partnered with Poudre Fire Authority for swift water training. Since each swift water rescue mission requires upwards of 20 personnel, the two agencies work together frequently on these types of calls. Members practiced self-rescue and swimming techniques and worked together on several rescues and recovery scenarios, including a scenario involving missing persons, the skills from which were put into action just over a month later on the Poudre. And while the members of LCDRT are highly trained and have specialized gear, many of the steps they take to stay safe on the river can help you stay safe too. Before recreating on our area rivers, LCDRT recommends:If you do\xc2\xa0find yourself in trouble on the river, float on your back with your feet pointed downstream. Then angle your body 45 degrees with your head is pointing towards the shore, and the river will naturally push you in that direction. If you find yourself stuck on a rock or the wrong side of the river, have someone call for help; LCDRT or one of their partner agencies will come to help you make it safely back to the right side.\xc2\xa0If someone else is in trouble in the river, never go in after them. Try to reach out to them with a sturdy branch or throw them a rope. Try to stay with them while you or someone else dials 911. If you lose sight of them, make a note of where you were when you last saw them. This \xe2\x80\x9cLast Seen Point\xe2\x80\x9d is crucial to rescuers as they determine where to focus their search efforts.LCDRT relies on community support to serve the citizens of Larimer County. If you\xe2\x80\x99d like to learn more about LCDRT, are interested in joining, or would like to make a donation, check out their website at www.lcdrt.org, or email info@lcdrt.org. The team is currently\xc2\xa0seeking new members, and no previous diving experience is needed to join. The need for shore-based members is as great as the need for members in the water.\xc2\xa0  Publisher’s Letter: Young Adults \xe2\x80\x94 Do You Read Us?Our new LiveMarket Local Offers lets you promote your business to locals 24/7. By Janice Bytheway
Larimer County Dive and Rescue Team, Vice President
Dive 55When you\xe2\x80\x99re a volunteer first responder, there\xe2\x80\x99s no predicting when you\xe2\x80\x99ll get a call, so on Saturday June 29, when Larimer County Dive Rescue Team was paged to respond to a rafter missing on the Poudre River near the Mishawaka, members abandoned their weekend plans to respond (one member even left the chair mid-haircut!). It was not the first time this season LCDRT had been called to the river, and it likely will not be the last, as rivers around Colorado are running high and fast after a cool, wet spring and above-average snowpack. Sadly, the number of people missing or killed on Colorado\xe2\x80\x99s rivers this year has risen into the double digits.\xc2\xa0While swift water season is LCDRT\xe2\x80\x99s most busy time of the year, the team responds to water rescue and recovery calls year round, assisting agencies around the county with ice rescue, dive rescue, and recovery of everything from sunken boats to criminal evidence. The team\xc2\xa0is equipped to respond anywhere in Larimer County, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, and spends one weekend per month training together, plus additional training time in the classroom and pool in order for members to earn the necessary\xc2\xa0certifications.\xc2\xa0In May 2109, LCDRT partnered with Poudre Fire Authority for swift water training. Since each swift water rescue mission requires upwards of 20 personnel, the two agencies work together frequently on these types of calls. Members practiced self-rescue and swimming techniques and worked together on several rescues and recovery scenarios, including a scenario involving missing persons, the skills from which were put into action just over a month later on the Poudre. And while the members of LCDRT are highly trained and have specialized gear, many of the steps they take to stay safe on the river can help you stay safe too. Before recreating on our area rivers, LCDRT recommends:If you do\xc2\xa0find yourself in trouble on the river, float on your back with your feet pointed downstream. Then angle your body 45 degrees with your head is pointing towards the shore, and the river will naturally push you in that direction. If you find yourself stuck on a rock or the wrong side of the river, have someone call for help; LCDRT or one of their partner agencies will come to help you make it safely back to the right side.\xc2\xa0If someone else is in trouble in the river, never go in after them. Try to reach out to them with a sturdy branch or throw them a rope. Try to stay with them while you or someone else dials 911. If you lose sight of them, make a note of where you were when you last saw them. This \xe2\x80\x9cLast Seen Point\xe2\x80\x9d is crucial to rescuers as they determine where to focus their search efforts.LCDRT relies on community support to serve the citizens of Larimer County. If you\xe2\x80\x99d like to learn more about LCDRT, are interested in joining, or would like to make a donation, check out their website at www.lcdrt.org, or email info@lcdrt.org. The team is currently\xc2\xa0seeking new members, and no previous diving experience is needed to join. The need for shore-based members is as great as the need for members in the water.\xc2\xa0  Publisher’s Letter: Young Adults \xe2\x80\x94 Do You Read Us?Our new LiveMarket Local Offers lets you promote your business to locals 24/7. Click below to get your 1st promotion going\xe2\x80\xa6 no credit card required, no strings attached.

\r\n EVERETT, Washington \xe2\x80\x94 An executive of state-owned EgyptAir said on Tuesday that British Airways' decision to suspend flights to Cairo, the Egyptian capital, for several days was "without a logical reason."

The vice chairman of EgyptAir Holding Co, Sherif Ezzat Badrous, told reporters at a ceremony marking the delivery of the carrier's newest Boeing Co 787 Dreamliner that Cairo airport is safe and EgyptAir continues to operate in a "very safe environment."

British Airways, part of International Airlines Group , suspended flights to Cairo on Saturday for seven days "as a security precaution" as it reviews security at the Cairo airport.

Later on Saturday, Germany's Lufthansa said it had canceled services from Munich and Frankfurt to Cairo, but it resumed flights on Sunday.

"What happened three days ago was unexpected completely, and without a logical reason," Sherif Ezzat Badrous said. "Until now, at this moment, we don't have any logical reason" for the actions taken by British Airways.

"You can ask them about the true reasons," he added.

On Sunday, Egypt's aviation minister, Younis Al-Masry, "expressed his displeasure at British Airways' taking a decision unilaterally concerning the security of Egyptian airports without referring to the competent Egyptian authorities," the Aviation Ministry said in a statement.

Other airlines were continuing to operate flights to Cairo.

Air France had decided to maintain its service to Cairo after liasing with French and Egyptian authorities, an airline spokesman said in a statement sent to Reuters. Emirates flights were operating to schedule, a spokeswoman said.

The website for Abu Dhabi's Etihad showed its services were also operating, and a spokesman said the airline was monitoring the security situation in Cairo. \xe2\x80\x94 Reuters

"Until now, at this moment, we don\'t have any logical reason" for the actions taken by British Airways."You can ask them about the true reasons," he added.On Sunday, Egypt\'s aviation minister, Younis Al-Masry, "expressed his displeasure at British Airways\' taking a decision unilaterally concerning the security of Egyptian airports without referring to the competent Egyptian authorities," the Aviation Ministry said in a statement.Other airlines were continuing to operate flights to Cairo.Air France had decided to maintain its service to Cairo after liasing with French and Egyptian authorities, an airline spokesman said in a statement sent to Reuters. For me the old DJI Phantom 3 Advanced drone was a try-out. I got it from a friend who switched to a newer model. Although the quality isn't that good for photography, I definitely got an idea of what was possibleOne of the first photos I took with a drone; a panorama of a nearby lake. Photographing with a drone is completely different and it can be difficult to find a good composition. (DJI Phantom 3 Advanced ISO100 f/2,8 1/200 - panorama from 3 images)The winding route of small brook. It almost looks like a miniature Amazon river. (DJI MAvic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/5 stack of 5 images)The same brook from the previous image, just from a few meters high. Although it does not look like a drone photo at first sight, this photo is not possible without it. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/160 panorama from 3 shots)This pond cannot be reached on foot because there is a ditch, trees, and bushes that prevent a good photo. But with the drone it is no problem. Just a few meters high, not more that thirty meter further. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/20 stack of 5 shots)The wonderful waterfall called Fossurin \xc3\xad Foss\xc3\xa1 at the Faroe Islands. The drone made it possible to take a much higher vantage point. I had to make a panorama to make the field of view large enough (DJI MAvic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/80 panorama from 8 shots)
I have been photographing this beautiful waterfall called Cascade de la Beaume many times, but never from this point of view. It is a great addition to all the other photos I have. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/5 Kase ND16)The planes of the Faroe Islands during sunset, looking towards Sl\xc3\xa6ttaratindur. The higher vantage point show a completely different landscape than from below. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/60)I did not know of these ponds in a nearby moorland, until I noticed it while flying the drone. Just twenty meters from the footpath, and not more than two meters high made it possible to shoot this sunset. (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/8 Panorama from 3 shots)These ponds in the moorland are almost impossible to photograph; you cannot reach it. But with the drone it is possible. Again, only from a few meters high to keep a normal perspective (DJI Mavic Pro 2 ISO100 f/5,6 1/400 panorama from 3 shots)Nando Harmsen is a Dutch photographer that is specialized in wedding and landscape photography. With his roots in the analog photo age he gained an extensive knowledge about photography techniques and equipment, and shares this through his personal blog and many workshops.For anyone using a drone, there is an excellent app called AirMap. It will help you to avoid no-fly zones in North America, perhaps elsewhere also.I use the app Drone Buddy. Works worldwide and is quite accurate concerning no-fly zonesWhen drones first came out, I thought about getting one for my industrial photography and I may yet do that but, having experienced their use on public lands, I would never get one for any other use. I liken them to your car's stereo: you like the music and think you're cool as you drive down the road, blaring it out your open windows but nobody else is into it. No, they're not as quiet as you think. Yes, they annoy everyone else.

We get a lot of support from turtle lovers all over the world but one of the longest and most unfailing relationships we have is with the Newport Aquarium in Cincinnati, Ohio. And this year intern Maria Woeste comes to us after serving an Aquatic Animal Husbandry internship with them last summer.Maria says her primary work was caring for the touch tank exhibit of cow nose rays, including distributing their food during public feeding times. And just like some of our patients there was one high-maintenance lady named \\"Blondie\\" who had to be fed separately. \\"Blondie was the biggest ray there and she just liked food way too much!\\" She also tended to the critters living in the fresh water exhibits.Maria is a Marine Biology major at Thomas More University and when she was exploring internships her mentor at the aquarium suggested she check into ours. She says that while some of the work is similar to what she was doing there our goal is clearly rehab and release. And the work is much harder, and the days much longer.At our hospital she once again finds herself spending much of her time with a very special and demanding lady, loggerhead \\"Snooki.\\" Not only is Snooki one of our visitors\' favorites she\'s the biggest turtle in Sea Turtle Bay. But Snooki is very, very particular about who she allows into her circle of caretakers. She checks out whoever is near her tank and if they\'re not on her approved list she rolls her eyes and keeps going with a \\"see ya\\" splash from her flipper. Apparently Maria has gotten her stamp of approval as she is the one in charge of Miss Snooki\'s feeding and medical treatments. Snooki demands calm and confident undivided attention while in her tank and Maria is the epitome of that.Although Maria worked at the touch tank at the aquarium and was used to guests hanging out there \\"I was not prepared for the huge number of visitors we get on tour days! I\'ve had to adapt quickly and I will say it has greatly improved my public speaking skills. I love it when someone asks a difficult question because it\'s a challenge to answer it in a way that\'s not only correct but is informational and inspires a love for all sea turtles.\\"In just a few weeks Maria returns to school as a rising junior where she will assume the duties of Social Media Rep for the Marine Biology Club. She\'s also active in the school\'s Biology Club and the Blue and Green Environmental Club which plans and executes environmental service projects. \\"This internship has changed my perspective on how I view marine biology as a whole. It\'s helped me grow in a lot of ways.\\" After graduation Maria hopes for a job in conservation and rehab, and envisions a future working with the larger marine animals like dolphins and sharks.We\'re into crossover season and the Topsail Turtle Project volunteers are burning the candle at both ends with nests in the morning and hatchings late into the night. As of this writing we have 156 nests and 8 hatches. Just looking at those numbers is exhausting for turtles and volunteers alike!Tour schedule: we\'re open daily (except Wednesdays and Sundays) from noon – 4 p.m. Lines can be long so prep for your visit by making sure that you are well hydrated and are wearing sunscreen. An umbrella can help provide shade if it\'s a hot and sunny day. The tour lasts approximately one hour once you are inside. Come in and talk turtle with us!Karen Sota is the volunteer media coordinator for the Sea Turtle Hospital in Topsail Beach.

We get a lot of support from turtle lovers all over the world but one of the longest and most unfailing relationships we have is with the Newport Aquarium in Cincinnati, Ohio. And this year intern Maria Woeste comes to us after serving an Aquatic Animal Husbandry internship with them last summer.Maria says her primary work was caring for the touch tank exhibit of cow nose rays, including distributing their food during public feeding times. And just like some of our patients there was one high-maintenance lady named “Blondie” who had to be fed separately. “Blondie was the biggest ray there and she just liked food way too much!” She also tended to the critters living in the fresh water exhibits.Maria is a Marine Biology major at Thomas More University and when she was exploring internships her mentor at the aquarium suggested she check into ours. She says that while some of the work is similar to what she was doing there our goal is clearly rehab and release. And the work is much harder, and the days much longer.At our hospital she once again finds herself spending much of her time with a very special and demanding lady, loggerhead “Snooki.” Not only is Snooki one of our visitors’ favorites she’s the biggest turtle in Sea Turtle Bay. But Snooki is very, very particular about who she allows into her circle of caretakers. She checks out whoever is near her tank and if they’re not on her approved list she rolls her eyes and keeps going with a “see ya” splash from her flipper. Apparently Maria has gotten her stamp of approval as she is the one in charge of Miss Snooki’s feeding and medical treatments. Snooki demands calm and confident undivided attention while in her tank and Maria is the epitome of that.Although Maria worked at the touch tank at the aquarium and was used to guests hanging out there “I was not prepared for the huge number of visitors we get on tour days! I’ve had to adapt quickly and I will say it has greatly improved my public speaking skills. I love it when someone asks a difficult question because it’s a challenge to answer it in a way that’s not only correct but is informational and inspires a love for all sea turtles.”In just a few weeks Maria returns to school as a rising junior where she will assume the duties of Social Media Rep for the Marine Biology Club. She’s also active in the school’s Biology Club and the Blue and Green Environmental Club which plans and executes environmental service projects. “This internship has changed my perspective on how I view marine biology as a whole. It’s helped me grow in a lot of ways.” After graduation Maria hopes for a job in conservation and rehab, and envisions a future working with the larger marine animals like dolphins and sharks.We’re into crossover season and the Topsail Turtle Project volunteers are burning the candle at both ends with nests in the morning and hatchings late into the night. As of this writing we have 156 nests and 8 hatches. Just looking at those numbers is exhausting for turtles and volunteers alike!Tour schedule: we’re open daily (except Wednesdays and Sundays) from noon – 4 p.m. Lines can be long so prep for your visit by making sure that you are well hydrated and are wearing sunscreen. An umbrella can help provide shade if it’s a hot and sunny day. The tour lasts approximately one hour once you are inside. Come in and talk turtle with us! Karen Sota is the volunteer media coordinator for the Sea Turtle Hospital in Topsail Beach.Original content available for non-commercial use under a Creative Commons license, except where noted.\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t

Tucked away behind trees off of Erda\xe2\x80\x99s Droubay road sits the Flying M Clydesdales Motel, a horse motel run by Alyssa Coombs and her mother, Mickey Falkner.\xc2\xa0The mother-daughter duo originally collaborated to make a successful run at horse competitions and have now opened a business, the first of its kind in Tooele County.\xc2\xa0In 1995, Falkner decided she wanted to raise her twin daughters, Alyssa and Shelley, on a farm instead of in Salt Lake City. Never having been to Tooele County before, Falkner saw an ad in the newspaper for six and a half acres that came with animals.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThe land was pretty bare, but as soon as we got here, we just knew this is where we should be,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt came with a horse, rabbit, dog, and too many cats to count,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs added.It took the move to Erda for Falkner to discover her interest in horses, even though she had grown up on a farm in Iowa. But the breed she became interested in is not your common riding horse \xe2\x80\x94 the tall Clydesdale.\xc2\xa0The twin girls grew up trying a little bit of everything, from rodeo to English riding, but the family didn\xe2\x80\x99t get into driving Clydesdales until Alyssa had left for college.\xc2\xa0Falkner had a friend help teach her to drive her feisty Clydesdale. After Coombs moved back home, they started to show their horses at different competitions.\xc2\xa0Their first horse passed away but now they own two Clydesdales: Strutt and Annabelle. After taking them to Wisconsin last year, Falkner decided to look into starting a horse motel since they had used one on their drive to and from Wisconsin.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHorse motels have been very popular for a number of years for all those traveling state to state for horse shows, buying and selling horses and other trips,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are quite unheard of by the general public, though. We are virtually an AirBnB for anyone traveling with their large animals.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The cost per animal is $20 a night. There is no lodging for owners, but they are welcome to stay in their trailer on the property.\xc2\xa0The horses are required to be in good health and have vaccination papers. Yet at no time are Falkner\xe2\x80\x99s and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 horses allowed to go nose to nose with visiting horses.\xc2\xa0Their horse motel is the only one within hours of Salt Lake City.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cA professional horse shipper just said she is thrilled there is now a horse motel in our county,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s great for show season, or buying or selling. A lot of people are having horses shipped state to state.\xe2\x80\x9dEvery stall comes with fresh bedding, but each customer needs to bring their own feed and water buckets.\xc2\xa0Their first guest horse traveled from Hawaii.This year they were invited to escort the Grand Marshal and his grandchildren at the Bit n\xe2\x80\x99 Spur Rodeo held at Desert Peak Complex during the July 3 and July 4 shows.\xc2\xa0Clydesdale horses don\xe2\x80\x99t rodeo, but have their own shows. Last October, Falkner and Coombs drove to Madison, Wisconsin, where they participated in the World Clydesdale Show.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt definitely takes a team,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said about what she has learned from participating and supporting her mom.\xc2\xa0Many people are needed to help assist in getting all the equipment, horses and everything prepared for a show. People will often hire help.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a really high equipment sport where you have to bring feed, harnesses, vehicles, cleaning equipment, rakes, brooms, and more to every event,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said.\xc2\xa0At the shows families rent out stalls for their horses, a stall for equipment, one for their own personal use \xe2\x80\x94 and sometimes even more stalls.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cEveryone works so well together,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe share a lot and are willing to help other families out if their child needs something to enter a competition.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0In Montana, Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 son, Declan, participated with her in the Pleasure Driving category where they took second place. That day it was windy and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 hat kept trying to blow away, so she had to hold it with one hand and try driving at the same time. They lost to their friend\xe2\x80\x99s mares, whom Coombs claims are the best.\xc2\xa0Next year they plan on letting Declan participate. Her youngest son Quinn, age 5, already loves being around the horses and Coombs trusts the Clydesdales more than a standard-sized horse, especially since Strutt and Annabelle are so easy going.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI love their personalities,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re super cool and sensible.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0One of the competitions they enter Strutt in is the obstacle course.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of tight turns and it\xe2\x80\x99s a speed event,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0Participants aren\xe2\x80\x99t given a trial course beforehand but a piece of paper that shows where the obstacles are. \xc2\xa0At the Wisconsin show, Coombs won the costume competition, beating out 40 entries. Coombs, an accomplished seamstress, had sewn her horse Strutt and herself skeleton costumes.When Coombs is not helping out with the horses she can be found sewing. A customer in Grantsville hired her to sew a three-piece suit for her horse to wear for their family pictures. There are no patterns for horses.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI had to go do fittings and come up with it out of my head,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cI got all of this scrap fabric all over the horse and then made cuts. We\xe2\x80\x99re all excited to see how the pictures turn out.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0For the last three Aprils, Falkner has hosted a clinic at Desert Peak to teach how to drive horses. A seven times world champion has participated and taught the students to drive better. Participants have come from as far as Colorado, Wyoming and Montana.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDraft horse people are genuinely very nice and open to teaching and welcoming,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey want more people to be involved.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Looking back on their experiences, Falkner and Coombs see that it takes teamwork to drive horses and now run a business. Together they make a pretty great team.Check out Flying M Clydesdales Horse Motel on Facebook.

Tucked away behind trees off of Erda\xe2\x80\x99s Droubay road sits the Flying M Clydesdales Motel, a horse motel run by Alyssa Coombs and her mother, Mickey Falkner.\xc2\xa0The mother-daughter duo originally collaborated to make a successful run at horse competitions and have now opened a business, the first of its kind in Tooele County.\xc2\xa0In 1995, Falkner decided she wanted to raise her twin daughters, Alyssa and Shelley, on a farm instead of in Salt Lake City. Never having been to Tooele County before, Falkner saw an ad in the newspaper for six and a half acres that came with animals.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThe land was pretty bare, but as soon as we got here, we just knew this is where we should be,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt came with a horse, rabbit, dog, and too many cats to count,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs added.It took the move to Erda for Falkner to discover her interest in horses, even though she had grown up on a farm in Iowa. But the breed she became interested in is not your common riding horse \xe2\x80\x94 the tall Clydesdale.\xc2\xa0The twin girls grew up trying a little bit of everything, from rodeo to English riding, but the family didn\xe2\x80\x99t get into driving Clydesdales until Alyssa had left for college.\xc2\xa0Falkner had a friend help teach her to drive her feisty Clydesdale. After Coombs moved back home, they started to show their horses at different competitions.\xc2\xa0Their first horse passed away but now they own two Clydesdales: Strutt and Annabelle. After taking them to Wisconsin last year, Falkner decided to look into starting a horse motel since they had used one on their drive to and from Wisconsin.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHorse motels have been very popular for a number of years for all those traveling state to state for horse shows, buying and selling horses and other trips,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are quite unheard of by the general public, though. We are virtually an AirBnB for anyone traveling with their large animals.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The cost per animal is $20 a night. There is no lodging for owners, but they are welcome to stay in their trailer on the property.\xc2\xa0The horses are required to be in good health and have vaccination papers. Yet at no time are Falkner\xe2\x80\x99s and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 horses allowed to go nose to nose with visiting horses.\xc2\xa0Their horse motel is the only one within hours of Salt Lake City.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cA professional horse shipper just said she is thrilled there is now a horse motel in our county,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s great for show season, or buying or selling. A lot of people are having horses shipped state to state.\xe2\x80\x9dEvery stall comes with fresh bedding, but each customer needs to bring their own feed and water buckets.\xc2\xa0Their first guest horse traveled from Hawaii.This year they were invited to escort the Grand Marshal and his grandchildren at the Bit n\xe2\x80\x99 Spur Rodeo held at Desert Peak Complex during the July 3 and July 4 shows.\xc2\xa0Clydesdale horses don\xe2\x80\x99t rodeo, but have their own shows. Last October, Falkner and Coombs drove to Madison, Wisconsin, where they participated in the World Clydesdale Show.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt definitely takes a team,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said about what she has learned from participating and supporting her mom.\xc2\xa0Many people are needed to help assist in getting all the equipment, horses and everything prepared for a show. People will often hire help.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a really high equipment sport where you have to bring feed, harnesses, vehicles, cleaning equipment, rakes, brooms, and more to every event,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said.\xc2\xa0At the shows families rent out stalls for their horses, a stall for equipment, one for their own personal use \xe2\x80\x94 and sometimes even more stalls.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cEveryone works so well together,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe share a lot and are willing to help other families out if their child needs something to enter a competition.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0In Montana, Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 son, Declan, participated with her in the Pleasure Driving category where they took second place. That day it was windy and Coombs\xe2\x80\x99 hat kept trying to blow away, so she had to hold it with one hand and try driving at the same time. They lost to their friend\xe2\x80\x99s mares, whom Coombs claims are the best.\xc2\xa0Next year they plan on letting Declan participate. Her youngest son Quinn, age 5, already loves being around the horses and Coombs trusts the Clydesdales more than a standard-sized horse, especially since Strutt and Annabelle are so easy going.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI love their personalities,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re super cool and sensible.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0One of the competitions they enter Strutt in is the obstacle course.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of tight turns and it\xe2\x80\x99s a speed event,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said.\xc2\xa0Participants aren\xe2\x80\x99t given a trial course beforehand but a piece of paper that shows where the obstacles are. \xc2\xa0At the Wisconsin show, Coombs won the costume competition, beating out 40 entries. Coombs, an accomplished seamstress, had sewn her horse Strutt and herself skeleton costumes.When Coombs is not helping out with the horses she can be found sewing. A customer in Grantsville hired her to sew a three-piece suit for her horse to wear for their family pictures. There are no patterns for horses.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI had to go do fittings and come up with it out of my head,\xe2\x80\x9d Coombs said. \xe2\x80\x9cI got all of this scrap fabric all over the horse and then made cuts. We\xe2\x80\x99re all excited to see how the pictures turn out.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0For the last three Aprils, Falkner has hosted a clinic at Desert Peak to teach how to drive horses. A seven times world champion has participated and taught the students to drive better. Participants have come from as far as Colorado, Wyoming and Montana.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDraft horse people are genuinely very nice and open to teaching and welcoming,\xe2\x80\x9d Falkner said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey want more people to be involved.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Looking back on their experiences, Falkner and Coombs see that it takes teamwork to drive horses and now run a business. Together they make a pretty great team.Check out Flying M Clydesdales Horse Motel on Facebook.

At a School Board meeting that otherwise may not have addressed the topic, Volusia United Educators President Elizabeth Albert asked School Board members to confront the elephant in the room: what happened at Mainland High School.Albert asked board members for an apology for teachers who came forward with concerns about the school's plan to give the majority of the school's freshmen a placebo Advanced Placement exam, instead of the legitimate one that would give them college credit if they passed. Instead, 336 students took a fake exam and believed it was the real thing, until news of the plan broke in June.Principal of the Daytona Beach high school Cheryl Salerno was reprimanded along with former Chief Academic Officer Teresa Marcks.[READ MORE: Volusia County school officials reprimanded for placebo AP exams at Mainland High][READ MORE: 'Placebo' test means no college credit for 336 Mainland AP students]The district finished its investigation into an anonymous complaint sent to the Florida Department of Education in June, and on July 15 released its verdict: that Salerno and Marcks had violated professional conduct standards.Since then, the district's top leaders have said little.In a release on July 15, Superintendent Tim Egnor said the decision not to give every student the official test, and to keep them in the dark, \"cannot be justified, and must be addressed.\"School Board Chairman Carl Persis was interviewed repeatedly about the investigation, and said he was \"deeply troubled\" by what the students experienced.And School Board member Ruben Colon called it \"fraud\" and \"a disruption.\"Albert wanted more.\"I never heard an apology to the teachers, the parents and the community,\" she said. \"Will you say today, publicly to these teachers, 'You did no wrong. You were following the directives of your supervisor. We're sorry we didn't listen to you.' \"She explained that one of her biggest concerns is hearing that students and parents will struggle now to trust their teachers — something now-sophomore Molly Reilly who took the course last year and was given a placebo exam said.\"I can't trust what (teachers) say,\" she told The News-Journal. \"You'd think (school) would be a very honest, safe place. Now it just seems fake and untrustworthy.\"[READ MORE: Scores soon available to Mainland students who took official AP exam over 'placebo'][READ MORE: Waiting for more details about 'placebo' AP tests, Mainland families feel deceived]Albert called this comment \"devastating,\" and emphasized that the three AP Seminar teachers at the school voiced concerns about the course and its implementation as early as last summer, but were directed to proceed anyway, and not to tell students they wouldn't all take the real test.\"The teachers were brave and bold and came forward and had articulated their concern from the beginning, but nobody listened,\" Albert said. She asked board members to publicly support them.At the end of the meeting, School Board member Ida Wright reaffirmed her support for the school.\"As an alumni of Mainland High I love Mainland, I support the teachers, parents, students and alumni,\" she said, quickly echoed by Jamie Haynes and Ruben Colon.Linda Cuthbert spoke in the same vein.\"A lot of things happen that are extremely good at Mainland High School,\" she said. \"I think you can go into any public school, anywhere, and there's going to be controversy. So we have to be supportive of the employees.\"And Persis pointed out that he has said multiple times he supports the teachers, but it doesn't always make it into the news coverage.Then the meeting adjourned.Since the conclusion of the investigation, Mainland Assistant Principal Robert Voges was transferred to another school. So was AP Seminar teacher Jason Kester. Salerno and AP Seminar teachers Vita Gaines and Mark Convoy remain at Mainland.[ALSO AT THE MEETING: Volusia School Board sets higher pay range in superintendent search][ALSO AT THE MEETING: Volusia School Board loosens uniform rules for high schoolers]

Two lifelong friends\xc2\xa0previously reported missing are now suspects in the homicides of a young tourist couple gunned down\xc2\xa0in Northern British Columbia\xc2\xa0last week, as well as\xc2\xa0in the suspicious death of another man whose body was found near the friends'\xc2\xa0burnt-out truck\xc2\xa0days later.RCMP said Tuesday that\xc2\xa0Kam McLeod, 19, and Bryer Schmegelsky, 18, are suspected of shooting\xc2\xa0Australian Lucas Fowler, 23, and American Chynna Deese, 24. The couple's bodies were discovered along the side of the Alaska Highway\xc2\xa0south of a popular hot springs tourist destination\xc2\xa0on July 15.Four days after the\xc2\xa0bodies of Fowler and Deese were found, McLeod and Schmegelsky's burnt-out truck was discovered\xc2\xa0near the community of Dease Lake, B.C., more than 470 kilometres away from the first crime scene.The body of an unidentified man in his 50s or 60s was found two kilometres south of that\xc2\xa0truck.McLeod and Schmegelsky were initially considered to be missing persons. Their families hadn't heard from them in days and said the pair, friends since elementary school, had been travelling to Whitehorse from their homes in Port Alberni on\xc2\xa0Vancouver Island in search of work.The pair is no longer considered missing and are now at large.\xc2\xa0They were last seen driving a grey\xc2\xa02011 Toyota RAV4 and Mounties said they may still be on the move.It is believed they've left British Columbia and may have been spotted in northern Saskatchewan, the RCMP said on Tuesday morning. Two employees at a hardware store in Meadow Lake, Sask., about 250 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon, told CBC News the suspects were in their store and made purchases, though it was not clear when.\xc2\xa0Later in the day,\xc2\xa0Manitoba RCMP\xc2\xa0said in a tweet they had "reason to believe" McLeod and Schmegelsky were recently in the Gillam area, in the northeast\xc2\xa0of the province.We are asking the public that if you spot Kam McLeod or Bryer Schmegelsky to consider them as dangerous - take no actions \xe2\x80\x93 do not approach \xe2\x80\x93 and call 911 immediately. <a href="https://t.co/RdhBNVr5im">pic.twitter.com/RdhBNVr5im</a>Officers said they may have changed their appearances and have asked anyone who sees them not to approach them."We are asking the public: if you spot Kam or Bryer, consider them dangerous," Sgt. Janelle Shoihet\xc2\xa0said during a press conference from the Lower Mainland on Tuesday. "Take no action and immediately call 911."Both McLeod and Schmegelsky are\xc2\xa0described as six feet, four inches tall and around 169 pounds.McLeod has dark brown hair, brown eyes and facial hair. Schmegelsky has sandy brown hair.Fowler and Deese were days into a three-week road trip and were\xc2\xa0bound for Alaska\xc2\xa0when they were killed. Fowler's weathered, soft blue 1986 Chevy van carefully chosen for the journey\xc2\xa0marked the crime scene at the side of the road.RCMP said the couple, who met abroad two years ago,\xc2\xa0likely died on July 14 or 15.\xc2\xa0Surveillance video shows Fowler and Deese hugging at a gas station, three days before they were killed:On Tuesday, Sgt. Janelle Shoihet said McLeod and Schmegelsky were seen near Dease Lake, the area in which their truck was found, on July 18.The red and grey Dodge pickup truck was outfitted with a camper. RCMP released a sketch of the deceased man found nearby on Monday and asked for the public's help identifying him.He is described as white and in his 50s or 60s with a heavy build and grey hair.\xc2\xa0RCMP Cpl. Chris Manseau said he would have stood between five feet, eight inches and five feet, 10 inches tall.Schmegelsky's father, Al, described the pair as "best friends" who met in elementary school. He previously said in an interview that the boys\xc2\xa0recently graduated high school and had just spent five weeks working at Walmart.Al\xc2\xa0Schmegelsky said his son and McLeod\xc2\xa0were disappointed with the\xc2\xa0Walmart gig \xe2\x80\x94 their first jobs \xe2\x80\x94 so they decided to head off in search of something better up north."They're just kids on an adventure. They're good boys,"\xc2\xa0Schmegelsky\xc2\xa0said Monday, speaking a day before his son and his friend were named suspects.The series of crimes has\xc2\xa0sent a chill through\xc2\xa0the northern region, an area known for its quiet seclusion and largely unaccustomed to heavy police presence. Friends have established "check-in" routines so they know loved ones are safe and some are no longer driving to work down remote highways alone.Mounties have been slow to release details on the specifics of the investigations, if at all, as is fairly common practice with the force in\xc2\xa0the province. RCMP have acknowledged heightened public interest in the cases, given how "unusual" crimes of serious nature are in the north \xe2\x80\x94 let alone more than one at once \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0but have declined to give further information\xc2\xa0for fear of jeopardizing ongoing investigations."The rumour mill is rampant," said Gail Andrews, whose family has run the\xc2\xa0Tetsa River Lodge at Mile 375 on the Alaska Highway for three generations. "It's become, 'Don't get out of your car, you'll get murdered.' People are nervous."Store owner\xc2\xa0Claudia Bunce says\xc2\xa0McLeod and\xc2\xa0Schmegelsky\xc2\xa0were in her shop earlier this month. They were captured on video,\xc2\xa0walking in for a cup of coffee, she says.Andrews said visitors and residents staying at the lodge heard\xc2\xa0sirens screaming by the property last week as police raced to the spot where Fowler and Deese's bodies were\xc2\xa0found about 100 kilometres away.Another missing persons case involving two men from Surrey, B.C. also made headlines alongside news of the investigations in the north, but RCMP confirmed Tuesday that case is unrelated to the homicides.With files from CHEK NewsAudience Relations, CBC

MINSK, 23 July (BelTA) \xe2\x80\x93 Forty-six children from Egypt will come to Belarus to spend summer holidays at the Belarusian national education and recuperation center Zubrenok. The matter was discussed at the meeting of Belarusian Education Minister Igor Karpenko with Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Arab Republic of Egypt to the Republic of Belarus with residence in Moscow Ihab Nasr, BelTA learned from the press center of the Education Ministry. The children will come to Belarus upon the invitation of Belarus President Aleksandr Lukashenko. The minister told the diplomat about the activities the children will be offered at the center. The children will be able to learn more about Belarusian history, national traditions, cultural heritage and places of interest. They will go on excursions to Minsk, Mir Castle and Nesvizh Castle, and Nanosy-Novoselie local heritage complex in Myadel District. The children will also visit Belarusian State University and Belarusian State Technological University. The parties also discussed educational partnerships. Igor Karpenko suggested training Egyptian specialists in Belarus. \xe2\x80\x9cBelarus has preserved the system of vocational training, with a broad range of competences covering all sectors of the economy. Resource centers were set up to teach skills the modern-day economy needs the most. Belarus could open such a center in Egypt and provide it with scientific and methodological support and the teaching staff,\xe2\x80\x9d the minister added.

column4: John Jay College Of Criminal Justice, New York, United States
column5:
Costa Rican authorities say tainted liquor is responsible for the recent deaths of 19 people. Since the beginning of June, fourteen men and five women between the ages of 32-72 have lost their lives after drinking contaminated alcohol in the small Central American country.On July 19, the Costa Rican Ministry of Health announced it had confiscated 30,000 bottles of counterfeit alcohol bearing labels from six reputable liquor manufacturers. The identical labels make the contaminated spirits indistinguishable from legitimate products. Authorities discovered lethal amounts of the chemical methanol mixed in bottles labeled Guaro Montano, Guaro Gran Apache, Aguardiente Estrella, Aguardiente Barón Rojo, Aguardiente Timbuka and Molotov Aguardiente. The Ministry of Health has issued a statement alerting the public not to drink these brands until their investigation is completed. They also warned that anyone selling bootleg liquor or any illegal alcohol may face criminal charges. “We deeply regret the lives that have been claimed because of the sale of beverages with liquor adulterated with methanol. I have instructed [the Health Ministry] and other authorities to collect all possible data…” Costa Rica President Carlos Alvarado Quesada tweeted on July 18.The deaths in Costa Rica occurred around the same time as the unexplained deaths of at least 10 American tourists at resorts throughout the Dominican Republic. ABC News reported that unlike the tourists who died in the Dominican Republic, all of the Costa Rican victims were citizens and that none of the spirits were consumed at a hotel. Here’s what you need to know.
\n\nThey believe the cause is methanol poisoning, but the ministry stressed that the information is “preliminary as investigations continue.”https://t.co/3G9Ho7x9Ol— New York Daily News (@NYDailyNews) July 21, 2019Methanol is an industrial alcohol commonly found in antifreeze and solvents. It’s cheaper and easier to manufacture than ethanol, the alcohol found in liquor, beer and wine, but is not meant for human consumption. Drinking a small amount of methanol is potentially fatal. Methanol and other chemicals are sometimes added to increase the volume of illegal alcohol and make drinks more powerful.“When you distill alcohol in an unregulated way, it’s actually quite dangerous,” Nathan Lent a biology expert at John Jay College of Criminal Justice told Vice. — Sky News (@SkyNews) February 9, 2019Most Americans are unaware of the dangers of drinking alcohol abroad thanks to tight U.S. regulations that ensure liquor safety at home. But according to the World Health Organization (WHO), “unreported” alcohol accounts for up to 25% of all alcohol consumed around the world. The International Alliance for Responsible Drinking (IARD) issued a 2018 report outlining the problem of counterfeit alcohol overseas. Tainted spirits are common in developing countries. They account for 19% of the alcohol sales in Costa Rica and 29% in the Dominican Republic. In February 2019, more than 154 people died after drinking homemade booze laced with methanol in India’s northeastern state of Assam. These “homegrown liquors” are typically produced in villages and then sold illegally in cities for about a third of the cost of lawful liquor. “Alcohol produced and sold illegally outside of government regulation is the most problematic part of unrecorded alcohol; it is untaxed, circumvents restrictions around availability, is of inconsistent quality, and, depending on the ingredients used to make it, is even potentially toxic,” the IARD’s report explained. — New York Post (@nypost) June 28, 2019The U.S. Embassy issued a statement on its website announcing that the FBI had sent a team to the Dominican Republic to assist Dominican authorities with toxicology tests.The New York Post reported that the FBI was testing liquor samples from the rooms of the tourists who died as well as blood samples from the deceased. Their findings have not been released. Last June, Senator Chuck Schumer appealed to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) as well as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to step in and assist the FBI with the investigation. “ATF & more CDC experts should help the FBI with fact-finding. Now,” he tweeted.— CTSSA (@CTSSA) June 19, 2019Initial methanol poisoning replicates the same symptoms of drunkenness: dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. Extreme methanol poisoning can lead to seizures and unconsciousness. Drinking just two to eight ounces can lead to lead to death.The CDC noted that methanol’s effects can take up to 72 hours to appear. According to Medline, permanent blindness can occur after drinking methanol.— Gregory Meriweather (@MeriAssociates) July 22, 2019Lent suggested taking a small amount of liquor and lighting it on fire. The flame will burn green or orange if the spirits contain methanol, and blue if the liquor is pure. “Anything that doesn’t burn blue is a cause for concern,” Lent noted. Lent said tourists should smell their liquor before imbibing since contaminated drinks may have an unusual odor. He also recommended that travelers steer away from clear alcohol, which is easy for bootleggers to replicate. Doing without alcohol in countries where bootleg liquor is a problem may be the safest option. “Tainted drinks are a real threat for vacationers,” Dr. Manny Alvarez wrote in a piece for Fox News.

"THERE IS no real transition from military life to civilian life for any veteran," says Pastor Candace Hardnett of Agape Empowerment Ministries. And she should know—she is a United States Marine Corps veteran.  “Literally you are trained for months and months on end to become a military member.” Hardnett received 18 months of training to become a Marine, “and when I got out, I was given a three day workshop on how to put a resume together and go on an interview. Bye, good luck, see you later,” she says.“There was no dismantling of who I had become—you literally become someone different and you are taught to kill and to have no worry or thought about it,” Hardnett recalls.“When you come out in the civilian world, you aren’t turned off—you were created and you weren’t uncreated—and you have to navigate that, and for some people, especially those who saw combat, it is almost impossible. How do you do that on your own?”Pastor Candace Hardnett, Father Michael Chaney, and Reverend Kevin Veitinger all work with some of the 4,200 people who are homeless in our community. They estimate that of the homeless people that they directly work with, about 25% are veterans.  “Veterans have gotten the shaft,” says Father Chaney. “The VA is understaffed and underfunded and they can’t really do their jobs to the fullest.  A lot of veterans are getting shoved out the door and they find themselves in positions where maintaining what we would call a normal life becomes really challenging and they don’t want to sleep inside because something feels safer about sleeping outside,” he says.“PTSD is very prevalent,” explains Hardnett.  “Not too long ago, there were certain branches that were removing people from service dishonorably for that (PTSD), they could not receive their veterans benefits, so some veterans were removed from service prematurely to not receive an honorable discharge for various stupid reasons.  You have to have paperwork in order to receive benefits. Paperwork becomes a barrier if you are dealing with all of the other stresses of living on the street.” “This group of people who volunteered to do this service, and some Vietnam era didn’t volunteer, they were drafted,” says Rev. Veitinger.  “And they are just forgotten about.”  “Jesus modeled this idea that we take care of people’s basic needs first,” says Veitinger, and that is what you will find every Sunday morning at The Community of St. Joseph, the outdoor church that he pastors in one of Savannah’s 26 different and unique outdoor homeless encampments.  “Sometimes the main goal is not to feed people,” says Hardnett. “Sometimes they just want to be heard.”Chaney says, “I am far less concerned with getting people to Heaven after they die than bringing Heaven to the world we are living in now.”  Veitinger adds to that thought.“Jesus didn’t talk a lot about afterlife Heaven, Jesus talked about this Kingdom of God and bringing forth the Kingdom of God and being active participants in it and that is our role as Christians,” he says.“We are called to be citizens of the Kingdom of God first, and to remember that that citizenship is to define our perspectives on things, and if we can do that, we allow that to inform our decisions on a daily basis.  I think that we could make a huge dent without the government’s help.”Hardnett adds, “Some of us are doing the leg work with the right heart intention, we are doing something about it, even if it is a small thing.  We are doing what we can do, what we know to do, and if everyone can do something, even if it is a small thing, we can actually put a dent in some of what we see and help as many people as possible.”“Man, it would be great if the government didn’t have to get involved, wouldn’t that be awesome?” exclaims Chaney. “If we were all really pulling our weight and taking care of our neighbors, oh what a happy day, the Kingdom would be coming into fruition. That ain’t happening though. I think that our country is in need of a great spiritual awakening, and I’m not talking about a religious awakening,” he says.“I’m talking about the kind of spiritual awakening where we really understand our neighbors and understand that all of us are walking different paths and encounter different obstacles in our life and it is up to us to really take care of one another.”Homelessness is extremely complex—this could be a weekly column all year and we still would not scratch the surface. From broken systems, housing first initiatives that in the long run cost the municipalities less, to the 9th US Circuit of Appeals prohibiting the criminalization of homelessness stating that governments cannot “criminalize conduct that is an unavoidable consequence of being homeless—namely sitting, lying, or sleeping on the streets”—everyone has a Constitutional right to sleep on a park bench, under a bridge, or on the public sidewalk, regardless of how some might think it looks to tourists.  The causes of homelessness are just as diverse as the population, from homeless veterans, to the train kids with their own unique hieroglyphic-type symbols, to the over one thousand homeless children that attend Savannah-Chatham County public schools.  Hiding the problem is not going to make it go away—and we need to all do better, from our elected officials, to each and everyone one of us looking out for our neighbors who live in tents.  “Little tiny things, like looking people in the eye to say hello.  You are not going to be robbed by a homeless person 999 times out of 1,000, but there is a dignity—offering people the dignity of looking them in the eye and say hello,” says Veitinger.“Ask them their name,” says Chaney. “Names are important and it brings back this basic human dignity that we take for granted that a lot of our friends lost.”The Community of St. Joseph Church meets every Sunday morning at 8 a.m. for breakfast, and 9 a.m. for praise and worship. Directions can be found on their Facebook page. I encourage all to attend, and bring something to share for the communal breakfast. Fresh fruit would be nice, because homeless people rarely get fresh produce.  Church of the Epiphany currently meets on Sundays at 11 a.m. at the Savannah LGBT Center at 1515 Bull Street and all are welcome. You can take donations to Padre Chaney and he will make sure that they get to where they are needed most.  If you aren’t able to attend a service, you can drop off donations at Emmaus House at 18 Abercorn Street or the Episcopal Diocese office at 18 East 34th Street.   In addition to dropping off at Agape Empowerment Ministries at 143 Telfair Road (Sunday service at 10 a.m. and Wednesday Bible Study at 6:30 p.m.), they have a partnership with the U-Haul located at 8810 Abercorn where you can drop off donations seven days a week. Non-perishable food items are greatly needed, along with bottles of water and bug spray.Veitinger concludes, “Until the big systems are fixed, we have to deal with the immediate needs of our homeless neighbors.”@ The Sentient Bean – A poetry and music open mic with an emphasis on… (more) @ Tybee Island Marine Science Center – The Tybee Island Marine Science Center\xe2\x80\x99s Marine Debris Ambassador, Admiral,… (more) Another solution: get a fake ID. That's what we did back in the day. » What could be more Oglethorpian than a "civic" center? » Built by the late jc lewis, I believe. Yes, needs to be demolished along wi » This is all chaff before the wind. These panels and boards mean nothing. Th » So the median personal income is less than $21,000 a year. It is bound to s » What's this schlep doing back here? A missed opportunity to tar and feather » Built by the late jc lewis, I believe. I have the very highest regard for those hard-working men and women who dedicate their energy, expertise and lives to the health care of others. But the system is broken and it can\'t be fixed without acknowledging its shortcomings.Two areas scream out for repair: eye to detail and timely followup. Often, stellar care at the point of entry is overshadowed and diminished by shoddy followup. We expect better. Ironically, the latest computer filing technology is not actually addressing simple concerns such as timely test results, accurate information regarding special medication instructions, and patient notification when specialist appointments (after many weeks of waiting) have changed. This lack of \\"eye to detail\\" matters to patients in building the trust required to turn their lives over to an (often) total stranger. Please note: The internet does not replace a real human doctor. Its information is iffy at best. We count on the experience, expertise and effort of doctors and nurses to use their immense skill to do very special work, not our home computer. Timely information from a human being takes a minute or two more, but is so important. Another frustrating shortfall involves the false notion that \\"hallway\\" hospital care is a relatively new thing. It is not. Thirteen years ago we took Mum to a local ER \xe2\x80\x94 we were the only ones in the waiting room. Once registered, she ended up on a gurney in the hallway all night \xe2\x80\x94 just us to walk her down a long hall to the washroom. The next morning, still in the hallway. Thirteen years ago! A family member had a heart attack several months ago and was given the option to stay another few days, likely in the hallway (no room guarantees), or head home. She went home. Somewhere along the line, this became acceptable. It is not.Additionally, when Hamilton was amalgamated years ago, how many hospitals were planned to accommodate the growing number of patients? Every single one of those added communities has grown leaps and bounds. Is there anyone who doesn\'t recognize baby boomers as a huge group already forging its way into the hallowed hallways of health care? It\'s time for honest assessment and diligent action. Code Red shared lots of reality checks \xe2\x80\x94 just the tip of this iceberg. Will the day come when a \\"gurney in the hallway\\" will be the benchmark of really good health care? I pray not. Given the shortage of doctors for family care, it can be tough to reach one\'s overworked GP in an emergency. They do their best, but patient overload makes it very difficult. Are the motions in place to recruit more doctors? Is there a better way to fill the growing gap? Is there any way the transition from a retiring doctor to another doctor could be facilitated with sensible incentives that actually work? Whatever is in place now \xe2\x80\x94 not sufficient. A caveat to all whose family member requires hospital care: be a presence. Ask questions. Indicate honestly if hearing impairment is an issue. Many elderly patients are embarrassed to indicate they can\'t \\"make out\\" what the doctor is saying. This can cause a great deal of stress and the dissemination of incorrect information. I read about a high school classmate\'s distress that his healthy mother went in for an elective surgery, unaware that there was a C. difficileoutbreak at the hospital. She survived the surgery only to die from complications due to C. diff. Heartbreaking. Had the family known, they most certainly would have cancelled and rescheduled the surgery. These are the kinds of things we have to ask. I wish we didn\'t have to \xe2\x80\x94 but we do. I don\'t know what the acceptable hospital morbidity rate is, but if you have ever lost a loved one to a flaw in the system, one is too many. Finally, there is no excuse for dirty hospitals. It is rampant and it is everywhere. No local hospital escapes the list. The cleaners work hard \xe2\x80\x94 we need more cleaners. By and large, we are living longer, acutely aware that it is our responsibility to try to maintain a healthy lifestyle. However, genetics, heredity, environment and random selection can throw a challenging curve ball at one\'s best efforts. Our hospitals and those working diligently within those walls deserve to have the best chance of doing what they do best: preserving and saving lives. There are solutions. It\'s time to find them and make them work. Paula Kent Kuchmey has been a writer and editorial consultant for over 30 years with a special interest in topics that effect children, the elderly, our most vulnerable.

Jul 24, 2019
